urn:contentItem:4PMC-C2B0-TX4S-M1H5-00000-00Fallout from Greek fires may be sign of changing climes2007-09-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisAPg. 11Fallout from Greek fires may be sign of changing climesThe Canberra Times

'H ow are our children going to survive in a land that is dead?"

asked a survivor of the wildfires that seared much of southern Greece during the last week of August. Six thousand homes and four million olive trees burned, half the forests of Greece gone, and 64 people dead is a huge loss, and in the carbonised landscapes of the Peleponnese it is hard to imagine that people will ever live there again.

But what nobody saw coming was the political fall-out: this may be the first time that a government falls because of climate change.

When the centre-right government of Costas Karamanlis called an early election last month after only three years in office, it had a comfortable lead in the opinion polls and was cruising towards a certain victory.

The fires changed all that, shaking people's trust in the competence not just of the Government but of the established parties in general. In the last published opinion polls (Greek law bans polls in the last two weeks before the September 16 election), neither Karamanlis's New Democracy nor the centre-left opposition party, PASOK, had even 40 per cent of the vote.

The beneficiaries were the extreme right Laos party, a normally marginal group preaching nationalism, hatred of immigrants and Orthodox Christianity (its posters urge all Greeks to unite as "one fist"), and the equally fringe party of the hard left called Syriza. Neither party is represented in the present Parliament, since they could not clear the legal threshold of 3 per cent of the popular vote.

They are both very likely to be in the next Parliament and if the two major parties end up more or less tied, as seems probable, extremists of one sort or another will be able to extort a high political price in return for agreeing to support a coalition government.

Obviously, we can't just extrapolate from this single example and say that climate disasters lead to a polarisation and radicalisation of politics, but this is a phenomenon that warrants attention. After a week like the Greeks had, there was bound to be a political reaction, but does it mean anything for other places?

First of all, were these fires really caused by climate change? After all, there were fires of a similar scale in Greece about a century ago, and of course the land did turn green again after a few years. But uncontrollable "megafires" are ceasing to be once- in-a-century events. Another one burned about a quarter of the island of Tenerife in the Canary Islands this summer.

There have been comparable megafires in the past few years in France, Portugal, Canada, Russia, Indonesia, South Africa and Brazil.

In the United States, where a forest fire that burned more than 2000ha was relatively rare 20 years ago, in the past decade there have been more than 200 megafires that burned at least 10 times that area.

Six of the past 10 years have seen the previous US record for the amount of land devastated by forest fires broken.

If this isn't climate change in full costume dress, it is certainly its first cousin. Temperatures in Greece this summer hit 46 degrees, unheard of even 10 years ago. In a Mediterranean climate where almost all the rain falls in the winter, this virtually guaranteed massive forest fires.

There is a prima facie case for seeing this as a manifestation of climate change so what about the political reaction in Greece? It has been ugly on every side.

The Karamanlis Government, having made few preparations for coping with massive fires despite the speed with which the problem has grown in recent years, was slow to respond to the crisis, and then tried to shift the blame for its failures by claiming that the fires were set by arsonists, saboteurs and terrorists. Its spokesmen rambled on about "asymetrical terrorist threats" and an "organised plan" to destabilise the country, but those Greeks paranoid enough to believe such claptrap did not forgive the New Democrats for their sins. Instead, they promptly shifted their votes to the extremists who promised to "crack down hard" on something or other.

It hardly matters what they crack down on. Minorities and immigrants are usually favoured by the far right, which will probably be the main beneficiary of these events in Greece, but it's pure symbolism, so the actual target doesn't matter. Any outsider or foreigner will do.

Now envisage a world where climate change is really hitting hard.

The Mississippi delta, various Pacific islands and a good deal of Bangladesh are disappearing beneath the waves. The Amazon is burning, the monsoon has failed for the third successive year in the Indian sub-continent, and Spain, Italy, Greece and Turkey are turning into deserts. Will people and governments be sweetly reasonable, seeking collaborative ways to cope with a shared international disaster?

Sure they will. Just as soon as they have shot down all the flying pigs.

Gwynne Dyer is a London-based independent journalist whose articles are published in 45 countries.

urn:contentItem:4P8H-NV40-TXN5-S1MB-00000-00BRIEFS1998-08-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisNEWSIn Brief OverseasPg. 9BRIEFS

US mother faces infanticide charge

PHILADELPHIA, THURSDAY. A 70-year-old woman has been charged with first-degree murder, accused of suffocating eight of her 10 children. Marie Noe smothered the children with a pillow or other soft object, District Attorney Lynne Abraham said. All had been declared healthy at birth and were developing normally. They were 13 days to 14 months old when they died over a 19-year period from 1949. Mrs Noe said they had died in their sleep and in each case was at home alone with them. Her lawyer, David Rudenstein, said Mrs Noe denies the charges.

Mormon accused of polygamy

SALT LAKE CITY. The arrest of a man accused of making his 16-year-old niece his 15th wife has resurrected the subject of polygamy in the Mormon Church and has embarrassed officials at its headquarters in Salt Lake City. David Kingston has been arrested on two charges of incest and may also be charged with violating a Utah state law prohibiting polygamy. If so, it will be the first prosecution for polygamy in more than 45 years. Leaders of the 10-million-member Church of Jesus Christ of the Latter-day Saints, which renounced multiple marriages more than a century ago, say they now excommunicate anybody caught engaging in polygamy.

Fierce fighting in Sri Lanka

COLOMBO. Fierce fighting between Sri Lankan troops and separatist Tamil rebels in the country's north and east has left at least 213 dead in the past two weeks, an army spokesman said today. There was no comment from the rebels on the latest fighting. Sri Lanka in June slapped censorship on war reporting by local and foreign media after the military stepped up its campaign to capture the highway.

Japan remembers Hiroshima bomb

HIROSHIMA. Sorrow mixed with anger on the 53rd anniversary of the world's first atomic bombing today as thousands gathered to remember the dead and renew their commitment to peace. Prayers for a nuclear-free world took on a grim new significance in the wake of Indian and Pakistani testing in May that many fear may have started a global drift back towards nuclear weapons. The bomb dropped on Hiroshima killed an estimated 140,000 people by the end of 1945, according to city records, with thousands dying of related illnesses afterwards.

Bulgarian dictator dead at 86

SOFIA. Bulgaria's former communist dictator Todor Zhivkov has died in a Sofia hospital at the age of 86, doctors said today. Mr Zhivkov ruled Bulgaria from 1954 until he was ousted in a bloodless coup by fellow party members in 1989. He was released from house arrest in September 1997 after becoming Eastern Europe's first communist leader to stand trial in 1991.

Key Palestinian minister resigns

RAMALLAH. Hanan Ashrawi, a leading member of Yasser Arafat's Cabinet, resigned today in protest at a reshuffle of the Palestinian selfrule Government and its handling of peace negotiations with Israel. "I've reached my own conclusions, it's a question of being honest. There is nobody above the law," she said. Dr Ashrawi, an independent, is a leading voice of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, and a crusader for Palestinian human rights who has challenged both Israel and Mr Arafat's PLO.

New fires flare near Olympia

ATHENS. A new forest fire broke out at dawn today near ancient Olympia, home of the Olympic games of antiquity, firemen said. Major resources were brought in to tackle the latest fire as officials feared that the ancient site might be damaged, a spokesman for the firefighting coordination centre said. Prime Minister Costas Simitis had interrupted his holidays to chair a special Cabinet meeting on Tuesday night as ministers were recalled to discuss the fires, thought to be deliberately lit.

urn:contentItem:3SMC-5RS0-0048-T55H-00000-00<published>1998-05-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:56:44Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>WORLD NEWS IN BRIEF</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">EGYPT SWIM</p><p nitf:lede="true"> CAIRO, May 5 AFP - An Egyptian military court today gave a suspended one-year prison sentence to an Israeli who swam to Egypt in search of asylum, and fined him $ A2,350.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Initially Mordechai Levy, 33, from the northern Israeli city of Tiberias was ordered detained for 15 days by the court and charged "with illegal entry" in Egypt.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Levy, 33, swam the short distance from the Red Sea resort of Eilat in Israel to Taba Port in Egypt on Sunday and demanded asylum "for personal considerations," an Israeli embassy spokesman said yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Judicials sources in Suez said the Israeli embassy was expected to pay the fine and Levy was to be sent back home immediately after that.</p><p>AFP</p><p>MEXICO FIRE</p><p> MEXICO CITY, May 5 AP - At least 14 civilians trying to put out a forest fire in the southern state of Puebla were killed when a sudden wind shift surrounded them in flames, media reports said today.</p><p> Fernando Larios Perez, an official with the regional Civil Protection department, told the official news agency Notimex that seven other people were seriously burned.</p><p> As many as four others were missing in the fire that started yesterday, state government spokesman Alejandro Perez told The Associated Press by telephone from Puebla City.</p><p> Hot, dry weather blamed on the El Nino phenomenon has contributed to a number of fires that have burned more than 10,000 hectares in Mexico this year.</p><p>AP</p><p> SAFRICA HAMAS</p><p> CAPE TOWN, May 5 Reuters - South African Muslim groups have invited Sheikh Ahmed Yassin, the founder of the militant Palestinian group Hamas, to visit the country, the foreign ministry said today.</p><p> Newspapers said Yassin planned to arrive in Johannesburg on Friday and travel to Cape Town on Sunday as a guest of organisations including the Muslim Judicial Council. The council declined to comment on the visit, citing security concerns.</p><p> Two South African cabinet ministers met Yassin in Saudi Arabia last month, enraging South Africa's Jewish community.</p><p> Yassin, currently touring the Middle East, said talks in London aimed at reviving the region's peace process could not be expected to bring progress because of US and British bias.</p><p>REUTERS</p><p> UK LAWRENCE</p><p> LONDON, May 5 PA - Veteran bandleader Syd Lawrence died early today aged 74.</p><p> The musician, who appeared for many years with his orchestra on comic Les Dawson's TV show Sez Lez, died suddenly at home a spokesman for his band said.</p><p> Lawrence, also backed Dame Vera Lynn and sold many thousands of copies of the 20-plus albums he released.</p><p> The Syd Lawrence Orchestra which he founded still continues to sell out concert halls around Britain even though he retired from touring in 1994.</p><p> PA</p><p>COLOMBIA MASSACRE</p><p> BOGOTA, May 5 DPA - At least 17 people were killed by squads of right-wing extremists in a daylight attack on the streets and houses of the Colombian village of Puerto Alvira in Meta province, officials said today.</p><p> The death squads, numbering about 200 heavily armed men, also reportedly abducted eight people and wounded seven others.</p><p> Rightist paramilitary groups and leftist rebels have been battling each other for years in the region.</p><p> DPA</p><p> CHINA RUSSIA</p><p> BEIJING, May 5 AP - China and Russia have opened a direct presidential hot line to improve understanding between the former communist rivals, the Foreign Ministry announced today.</p><p> The secure telecommunications link, China's first with a foreign capital, will allow presidents Jiang Zemin and Boris Yeltsin to "exchange views on bilateral relations and international issues at any time," a spokesman said.</p><p>US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan signed an agreement for a US-China hot line last week, but the spokesman said he did not know when it would open.</p><p> AP</p><p> ENDS WORLD DATELINES    <br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SMC-5RS0-0048-T55H-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="645"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:444P-8H20-015G-S0DM-00000-00<published>2001-10-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:56:44Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES; Pg. 74</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>A great leap of life</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>SHAUNAGH O'CONNOR</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">SHAUNAGH O'CONNOR meets the man whose whisper found millions of listeners</p><p nitf:lede="true">Nicholas Evans admits he goes to bed with all his readers. He's not speaking literally of course -- he may well have the energy for a small readership, but being a bestselling writer means he now has millions of readers around the world.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "You go to bed with these people, they take your book to bed with them and put it on their night stand," Evans says.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "And you share this quiet time, just the two of you, and that's a wonderful thing."</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>Evans is best known for his first work, The Horse Whisperer, which was made into a movie starring Robert Redford and Kristin Scott Thomas. That book was the first time Evans exhibited what was to become his trademark: taking strangebuttrue, intriguing occupations and turning them into blockbuster stories.</p><p> The Horse Whisperer was about American horse trainers from what was once the wild west who can "speak" to their charges, communicating in "horse language".</p><p> Evans' new book, The Smoke Jumper, takes a special breed of firefighter, those who are airlifted into fires to save people trapped inside infernos.</p><p> Evans' books generally mix romance with rugged heroes and adventure tales and The Smoke Jumper is no exception.</p><p> Jumpers Ed Tully and Connor Ford are best friends, both in love with Julia, who must choose between the two men.</p><p> Connor is also a photographer who travels through Africa to capture images of disaster and despair. No one could accuse Evans of choosing material that lets him sit back and relax.</p><p> He sets himself huge research tasks each time he writes a novel.</p><p> "That stems from a journalistic background, in the sense that that was my first job," Evans says.</p><p> "Real life is just so rich and the process of research is crucial to me.</p><p> "If you're going to make a character who's a smoke jumper you need to know what you're talking about.</p><p> "As a reader you have no experience of these areas I'm writing about and accept it as plausible.</p><p> "But the people involved in that area should see it as real, too.</p><p> "If somebody working with horses saw that I had done something completely wrong in The Horse Whisperer, it would really bug me, so I just want to get it right."</p><p> The man who sets his stories in the American west is, in fact, a mildmannered English person who lives on an idyllic Devon property where the River Dart runs through into a wooded glade.</p><p> He lives with partner Charlotte and dog Hopi, "the second love of my life".</p><p> Evans came to writing novels after studying law, working as a newspaper journalist and then making TV documentaries as well as movies.</p><p> He came across the notion of smoke jumpers at the same time he was thinking about major life choices. His 25year marriage was coming to an end and he thought fire was a great metaphor for purging, clearing and starting again.</p><p> And jumping into the flames of a forest fire seemed a great metaphor for leaping into what life has to offer. He says he wanted to describe that moment in our lives when we have to choose between either the decent thing -- "the honour or the loyalty or things we're brought up thinking are the things we should stay with" -- or ambition.</p><p> "And whether you have the guts to jump into the flames to go and get it," the author says.</p><p> Evans knows people wonder what an Englishman is doing writing about the American west, but explains the west is his subject matter because "I was an Indian for the first 10 years of my life".</p><p> Playing the children's game of cowboys and Indians was a favourite hobby when he was young, with just an older sister for company.</p><p> "If you're a boy and you have an older sister they're like a generation apart, they're so sophisticated," Evans says.</p><p> "You want to play with them, but they don't want to play with you."</p><p>  * The Smoke Jumper by Nicholas Evans, Bantam Press, rrp $45</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:3S66-VHB0-0048-T4YN-00000-00<published>1998-03-10T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:56:44Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Western Australian Regional; Features</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: FIRES RETURN TO CAST A PALL OVER INDONESIA</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Geoff Spencer (with photos NY198-1990</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">BALIKPAPAN, Indonesia, AP - Five men, some with shoes, others barefoot, trudged up the smoky forest highway toward a wall of flames.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "We're here to put out the fire. The authorities gave us these," one said, proudly referring to a battered plastic water tank strapped to his back.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Until now, he explained, they had to beat flames out with tree branches.</p><p>This time, they walked about three kilometres from the nearest water hole to fill each 15-litre tank. When they finish dousing this fire, they will walk back, refill and hike to another blaze, he said.</p><p> Wildfires that poured choking smoke across much of South-East Asia and threatened the health of an estimated 70 million people last year have returned to the jungles of Borneo island.</p><p>Indonesia's worried neighbours have demanded strong action. But bogged down in its worst economic crisis in three decades, Indonesia admits that without heavy rain it has almost no chance of preventing haze from spreading across the region again.</p><p> Most days, a heavy haze blankets the cities of Balikpapan and Samarinda, both about 1,200 km north of Jakarta. Their airports have been closed much of the time since the first fires started in January.</p><p> Here the sun burns orange in a grey sky. Smoke fills the nose, irritates the throat and stings the eyes. Doctors warn of a dramatic increase in respiratory infections and asthma if the haze persists.</p><p> "We could face major health problems if it does not rain soon," said Dr Jusuf, the head of a hospital in Samarinda.</p><p> The smoke is worst in two national parks that are home to rare species such as orangutan apes.</p><p> Scientists warn that together with drought, the haze could devastate harvests as it did last year when crops could not get enough sunshine to grow.</p><p> "The smoke has ruined my crop. Fruit from my trees is too small to sell," complains Kondo, a farmer who lives on the edge of the burning forest.</p><p> As last year, officials have said many of the fires appear to have been set, a cheap way for farmers, plantation owners and logging companies to clear land.</p><p> Officials using satellite imaging count between 400 and 600 hotspots a day in eastern Borneo and dozens more in central Sumatra island. Fires have also been spotted in the Malaysian-controlled northern part of Borneo.</p><p> At this time of year, these locales should be green, lush and wet. But meteorologists say El Nino has cut short the rainy season, leaving jungles, farmland and commercial forest areas tinder-dry.</p><p> The government says about 8,900 hectares of land have been blackened in Borneo. But Grant Beebe, a forest fire expert from Boise, Idaho, said the damage could be in the hundreds of thousands of hectares.</p><p> Several hundred soldiers, firefighters and farmers are battling the fires with buckets or branches of trees, said Beebe, who works for a German-funded aid project monitoring the problem.</p><p> They haven't had much success, he said, but "it's an improvement on the past when people just let fires burn. At least now they know they should at least try to control them."</p><p> When the fires first started in Borneo costly water bombing planes were sent up for a few days - to little effect.</p><p> The government then began a cloud-seeding operation in which a plane drops salt crystals into clouds to induce rain. But so far that also has failed.</p><p>Indonesia's neighbours seem resigned to another year of choking on Indonesia's smoke. In Singapore, the state-owned television advised people to get their air filters and face masks ready.</p><p> "Prepare early and well for the full impact of El Nino," viewers were warned this week.</p><p>AP gr</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3S66-VHB0-0048-T4YN-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="610"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:3S9J-8320-0048-T05K-00000-00<published>1998-03-25T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:56:44Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: INDONESIANS FACE LOSING BATTLE AGAINST WILD BORNEO FIRES</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Kieron Flynn</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"> BUKIT SUHARTO, Indonesia, March 25 AFP - The young soldiers and civilian youths giggle as they stamp on creeping flames on a steep ridge in what was once one of the world's most pristine forests.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Troops use their boots to extinguish smouldering grass, while beating ineffectually at foot-high flames with shovels and rakes. The youths, some of them barefoot, join the fight with even cruder equipment, including lumps of wood and half-full buckets of water from a muddy and nearly empty nearby creek.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> With the firefighters spread over less than 50 metres as a two-kilometre wall of fire moves towards them through the rugged Bukit Suharto area of Indonesia's East Kalimantan province it is difficult to see the reason for their mirth, unless it is in the utter hopelessness of their task.</p><p>This is the frontline  one of scores of such frontlines  in<br/> what experts are saying is one of the greatest environmental disasters faced by the world today.</p><p> Some 1,000 fires are burning over 200 square kilometres in the province. They have razed about 200,000 hectares of forest and caused $ US220 million ($ A329 million) damage since the start of the year, according to officials and firefighters.</p><p> Thick smoke blocks out the sun in the provincial capital of Samarinda, the oil town of Balikpapan and other areas, leaving thousands wheezing and suffering skin and eye irritations. One person reportedly died here last week from a respiratory ailment linked to the smog.</p><p> Others are falling sick from poor water quality, the result of a dramtic drop in river levels because of a prolonged drought.</p><p> The fires have raised fears that last year's devastating haze, which disrupted transport and caused health problems over much of the region, could be repeated.</p><p> On the 125-kilometre highway linking Samarinda and Balikpapan, residents continue to pour water into the dust surrounding their wooden homes in what has proved until now an effective shield against the flames.</p><p> "My crops are burned but my house is okay," said one elderly woman in a village in Bukit Suharto.</p><p> The highway by night is illuminated by the thousands of slowly burning trees on either side, traffic slowing to pass through the smoke as flames melt the bitumen at its edges.</p><p> Fires are also burning southwest of Balikpapan and in the Kutai national park north of Samarinda, where endangered animals including orangutan flee the flames.</p><p> On the approach to Samarinda, the brothel settlement of Sepuluh Kilometre is surrounding by blackened earth and the hundreds of prostitutes and clients cough as they go in and out of scores of bars.</p><p> "Business is bad," said a guard at the entrance to the village.</p><p> "There have been fires here before and now the forests here are burning, people think it is dangerous."</p><p> Firefighters blame timber and plantation companies and small-holding farmers for the fires, saying indigenous Dayak tribes have centuries of experience in controlling the fires.</p><p> Satellite photos place many of the latest blazes within timber and palm oil concessions, though the companies deny they are using fire to clear land for fresh planting.</p><p> Farmers are more forthright, saying they need to burn trees and bush so they can plant fresh crops.</p><p> The disastrous Bukit Suharto blazes began several weeks ago when a farmer decided he needed a new peppercorn field, officials say.</p><p> Pepper is the area's main crop and the fires and drought of last year led to a shortage which in turn has forced prices up.</p><p> "So the farmers think they can get higher prices and want to plant more peppercorn," said Hartmut Abberger, of the German-funded Integrated Forest Fire Management Project in Samarinda.</p><p> "But if there is more pepper, the price will drop, and if they start more fires they could lose their own crops anyway. Its crazy."</p><p>AFP  ts<br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3S9J-8320-0048-T05K-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="647"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:8036-H1H1-2RYX-14M0-00000-00OPINION / LETTERS2010-08-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 47OPINION / LETTERS

Shop fire doesn't stop the news

WE would like to commend Andrew and Cathy, the proprietors of the Terrigal Newsagency which was damaged by fire last week, for their magnificent efforts in keeping newspaper distribution going.

Despite losing all their facilities the newspapers kept being delivered as normal.

Thanks to the generosity of Terrigal Surf Club, they are able to continue selling papers daily.

We would encourage other residents to support them at this difficult time.

Ted and Elaine Sandeman,

Terrigal

Netball players and fans court disaster

AS a female and netball enthusiast of 40 years standing I can't help but admire the new sporting fields and facilities being built for the predominantly male sports with the support of Wyong Council.

Don't get me wrong, these fields are needed in our growing region. But my blue eyes turn green when I see their car parks.

I compete at Baker Park knowing that to do so one risks life and limb to find safe parking within cooee of the netball courts. In Wyong every netballer plays their games at the same location on a Saturday, regardless of where they live.

The traffic congestion and danger that accompanies more than 2200 players, officials and thousands of family members all converging on this small patch of ground has to be seen to be believed.

To give you an idea the whole netball complex of 30 courts and clubhouse facilities would fit easily inside two professional soccer fields.

The courts have parking for about 35 cars in a weed-infested, poorly marked car park.

There are ways to help ease this traffic gridlock: angle parking, demolish and return the derelict tennis club site to parking or turning the unused road off Pollock Ave into a car park. I am sure that the council can find more solutions if they really try.

Lorinda Lombardelli,

Alison

Speeding drivers deserve to be fined

GOSFORD councillor Craig Doyle and those who support him in opposing the introduction of speed cameras, hidden or otherwise, are behaving disgracefully.

These cameras do save lives and avoid injuries despite his rubbery statistics that contradict those from the RTA.

We've just had thousands of dollars spent installing security cameras in various places around town to reduce crime in the area.

Why should the roads be any different? The next speeding driver booked could well save a life. As a driver for more than 40 years, I've had a few speeding fines and deserved each one.

David McDougall,

Woy Woy

Welcome to the NIMBY Coast

I READ with astonishment Jennifer Hatton's objections to the long overdue refurbishment of the scenic walking route of The Esplanade at Terrigal (Express Advocate, July 28).

The awful chicken wire fencing surely a relic from the 1950s has been replaced by a proper, tasteful metal fence and a concrete safety barrier installed on the roadside to protect pedestrians. Yet we have an objection.

It seems as if nothing can be done on the Central Coast without people objecting.

Want to sink a warship for a major tourist attraction, build a skate ramp to entertain children, look for gas way out to sea, build a race track to provide a major sporting facility and generate tourism revenue or maybe just want to smarten the place up?

Well forget doing it on the Central Coast - we're the NIMBY Coast where very little gets done and what does gets objected to.

I'm certainly not in favour of laissez-faire development but all this negative whingeing is dragging the Central Coast down.

John Shingleton,

Terrigal

Brown water from tap rates poorly

I HAVE just received my new rates notice with an increase of $178 a year. Then I turned my tap on and brown water came out.

Is this what I am paying my extra rates for?

Well done Gosford Council. Can they now tell me how I am going to stretch my pension even further to cover this increase.

Marjorie Hines,

Wyoming

Politics prevents reduction burning

THE findings of the Royal Commission into the 2009 Victorian Black Saturday bushfires have been released.

One recommendation is that fuel reduction burning be drastically increased.

I would like to know how much reduction burning has been carried out in Wyong shire throughout the winter months.

Former Victorian forest fire chief Athol Hodgson was interviewed on radio and said there was no political will to reintroduce the necessary fuel reduction to make the State fire safe because the Labor Government is too concerned about Green preferences.

When will our State Government and our local councils allow the Rural Fire Service to do its job and carry out the necessary fuel reduction burning to keep the people safe.

Or do they want a repeat of the Victorian disaster?

Anne Guest,

Wyee

Pensioners should be looked after

PENSIONERS deserve a boost in the pension now not down the track or just before they die.

What does it say about Australia, a rich country which ranks at the bottom of the developed countries, when it comes to the support of its senior citizens.

The big corporations can raise their prices as often as necessary to ensure a desirable level of profit, but the retired person whose income depends on a state pension is simply forced into the ranks of the country's impoverished.

Politicians spare a thought for the pensioner who opens a tin of generic baked beans and spreads them on week-old bread as you gorge into your T-bone steak at the Parliament House canteen at cut price, thanks to the generosity of the Australian taxpayer.

Richard Ryan,

Summerland Point

urn:contentItem:4P85-18H0-TXN5-R2H9-00000-00One dead, seven hurt in blazing tanker1998-01-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 1One dead, seven hurt in blazing tankerTrapped in the middle of an infernoLES KENNEDY and GREG BEARUP

A volunteer firefighter died and seven others were burnt, three critically, when they were trapped in their blazing tanker in a Southern Highlands State forest yesterday.

The injured included a married couple, both in a critical condition, and a father and son.

The eight had taken refuge under fire blankets inside the tanker after the blaze turned suddenly and raced towards them on Gulf Creek fire trail, about seven kilometres east of Wingello in Wingello State Forest.

The fire, driven by 120 km/h winds, leapt a kilometre in just 30 seconds and engulfed the tanker, which was destroyed within minutes.

Other brigades nearby heard the distress calls of the stricken firefighters over shortwave radio. All were members of the NSW Rural Fire Service Wingello Volunteer Bushfire Brigade.

Police have not released the name of the dead man, who had three young children and had been a brigade member for many years.

The injured include Mrs Gail Pritchett, 40, who is in a critical condition in Royal North Shore Hospital, and her husband, Mr Frank Pritchett, 40, also listed as critical in Westmead Hospital.

Mrs Pritchett received burns to 20 per cent of her body, including her airways, and was in intensive care and on a ventilator last night.

Mr Mick Neale, an experienced firefighter who is a teacher at St Patrick's College, Goulburn, is in Westmead Hospital in a critical condition and his son, Mr Andrew Neale, is in Bowral Hospital in a satisfactory condition.

Mr John Luke and Mr Roger Robinson are both in a satisfactory condition in Liverpool Hospital, and Mr Mike Young, 32, son of a local general store owner, is in a stable condition in Royal North Shore.

Police said the man's body was still in the tanker at 9 pm and was expected to be removed by late last night.

"He was a really reliable fellow," said Mr David Lidgard, who runs the shire canteen for Bundanoon Fire Brigade. "Wingello was a brigade that should never have been lost. They are well trained and dedicated."

Senior Constable Bob Eagleton, of Bowral police, said: "It looks like the fire has turned with a gust of wind and they have been caught in the truck.

"It's just a terrible disaster. Everyone feels it so badly. I'm a six-foot-tall pretty tough fella and this has had a terrible effect on me and all the other emergency workers."

A police chaplain arrived to counsel firefighters. There are 700 volunteers in the district.

It was the second fire death to hit the area in three years. Mr Bob Page, a member of the Wingecarribee Shire firefighters, was killed in 1994 fighting fires around Grafton.

The death was the fourth in four weeks to strike the Rural Fire Service in a summer that Commissioner Phil Koperberg has warned might be one ofthe worst bushfire seasons on record.

As police investigated the tragedy, more than 700 volunteer firefighters, backed by 17 helicopters and nine fix-winged aircraft, were battling fires at 32 locations throughout the State. So far, the fires have destroyed more than 200,000 hectares of bush.

One of the worst forced the evacuation of more than 1,200 campers from the Myall Lakes National Park on the mid-North Coast.

The fatal Wingello State Forest fire was one of three still burning in the Wingecarribee Shire last night.

The Minister for Emergency Services, Mr Langton, last night announced an immediate investigation into the death.

PAGE 2: Volunteers rally to fight deadly blaze; more pictures, map.

Two illus: One of the injured Wingello volunteers is taken from a helicopter into Westmead Hospital. Photograph by MICHAEL BUNN. An exhausted Wingello victim arrives at Royal North Shore Hospital. Photo by RICK STEVENS.

urn:contentItem:4P85-1CN0-TXN5-R2J2-00000-00A lot of smoke, but where's the fire?1998-03-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisSPECTRUMPg. 13A lot of smoke, but where's the fire?Sandra Hall

Firestorm

Written by Chris Soth

Directed by Dean Semler

Rated M

Hoyts Centre and suburbs. Greater Union and Village suburbs. Selected independents.

Former pro football star Howie Long quickly becomes part of the scenery in his screen debut - an action adventure about a gang of fire fighters at work in the Wyoming state forests. With a neck like a tree trunk, a face seemingly chiselled out of pine and an acting style to match, he could beat a forest fire to death, if he didn't first bore it into submission. He's not quite what Jerry Seinfeld calls a slow talker, but he's getting there, and this is not dialogue to linger over. "You're going to pound some more ground before you fly the sky," is fire chief Howie's idea of putting a little backbone into one of his less agile trainees.

The script was written by Chris Soth, a University of Southern California film student, and produced by his USC professor who successfully pitched it to Twentieth Century Fox. It would be interesting to know if anybody actually read it during its progress across the lunch tables of Hollywood, although I suspect not. The basic idea was probably enough to swing the deal. Howie and his team are "smokejumpers" - firefighters who parachute into burning forests which can't be reached any other way. Are they mad? The script doesn't go into that question. Psychology is not on its beat. It gets them in there and out again, strewing assorted complications in their path, while you suspend disbelief if you can - a feat which would be easier it you had a few more practicalities to work with. Soth isn't strong on logic. Nor does he trust the fearsomeness of the fire to keep the plot revved up, which is a pity, because Australian cinematographer Dean Semler, directing for the first time, turns on quite a show. A display of radiant heat and billowing vapours lighting up the sky, burning up the ground and almost eating up the screen. You're able to study it from so many angles that its changes of mind and mood are more than enough to keep the main plotline going - although Soth isn't convinced. As a result, he throws in a gang of escaped convicts, led by William Forsythe, a good actor when the circumstances are right, but completely baffled by his role here. He plays a sort of paste-up of villains gone by. Discernible are borrowings from Hannibal Lecter and Cape Fears Max Cady, but the basics of a characterisation are nowhere to be found. A criminal mastermind who speaks grammatically and calls his prison mates "Mr.", this man has spent his years inside becoming a whiz at physics and chemistry, and still he has to be told by Howie that fires run uphill.

Should be be played for laughs? Unable to make up his mind, Forsythe settles for being a bad Joke. Semler should have been able to help him. Unfortunately, he's not nearly as good with actors as he is with smoke and flames. While Forsythe hams it up, Howie doesn't act at all, and Scott Glenn, who actually manages a performance, has nowhere to take it, as Semler pumps up the music and lays on the bathos. Finally, it's the script that defeats them all. The clunk, clunk of those lines is enough to put out anybody's fire.

ILLUS:Lucky Luciano, capo di capos (an elegant Andy Garcia)

urn:contentItem:8036-H1H1-2RYX-14C9-00000-00Letters to the Editor2010-08-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 51Letters to the Editor

Netball players and fans court disaster

AS a female and netball enthusiast of 40 years standing I can't help but admire the new sporting fields and facilities being built for the predominantly male sports with the support of Wyong Council.

Don't get me wrong, these fields are needed in our growing region. But my blue eyes turn green when I see their car parks.

I compete at Baker Park knowing that to do so one risks life and limb to find safe parking within cooee of the netball courts. In Wyong every netballer plays their games at the same location on a Saturday, regardless of where they live.

The traffic congestion and danger that accompanies more than 2200 players, officials and thousands of family members all converging on this small patch of ground has to be seen to be believed.

To give you an idea the whole netball complex of 30 courts and clubhouse facilities would fit easily inside two professional soccer fields.

The courts have parking for about 35 cars in a weed-infested, poorly marked car park.

There are ways to help ease this traffic gridlock: angle parking, demolish and return the derelict tennis club site to parking or turning the unused road off Pollock Ave into a car park. I am sure that the council can find more solutions if they really try.

Lorinda Lombardelli,

Alison

Speeding drivers deserve to be fined

GOSFORD councillor Craig Doyle and those who support him in opposing the introduction of speed cameras, hidden or otherwise, are behaving disgracefully.

These cameras do save lives and avoid injuries despite his rubbery statistics that contradict those from the RTA.

We've just had thousands of dollars spent installing security cameras in various places around town to reduce crime in the area.

Why should the roads be any different? The next speeding driver booked could well save a life. As a driver for more than 40 years, I've had a few speeding fines and deserved each one.

David McDougall,

Woy Woy

Politics prevents reduction burning

THE findings of the Royal Commission into the 2009 Victorian Black Saturday bushfires have been released.

One recommendation is that fuel reduction burning be drastically increased.

I would like to know how much reduction burning has been carried out in Wyong shire throughout the winter months.

Former Victorian forest fire chief Athol Hodgson was interviewed on radio and said there was no political will to reintroduce the necessary fuel reduction to make the State fire safe because the Labor Government is too concerned about Green preferences.

When will our State Government and our local councils allow the Rural Fire Service to do its job and carry out the necessary fuel reduction burning to keep the people safe.

Or do they want a repeat of the Victorian disaster?

Anne Guest,

Wyee

Pensioners should be looked after

PENSIONERS deserve a boost in the pension now not down the track or just before they die.

What does it say about Australia, a rich country which ranks at the bottom of the developed countries, when it comes to the support of its senior citizens.

The big corporations can raise their prices as often as necessary to ensure a desirable level of profit, but the retired person whose income depends on a state pension is simply forced into the ranks of the country's impoverished.

Politicians spare a thought for the pensioner who opens a tin of generic baked beans and spreads them on week-old bread as you gorge into your T-bone steak at the Parliament House canteen at cut price, thanks to the generosity of the Australian taxpayer.

Richard Ryan,

Summerland Point

Welcome to the NIMBY Coast

I READ with astonishment Jennifer Hatton's objections to the long overdue refurbishment of the scenic walking route of The Esplanade at Terrigal (Express Advocate, July 28).

The awful chicken wire fencing surely a relic from the 1950s has been replaced by a proper, tasteful metal fence and a concrete safety barrier installed on the roadside to protect pedestrians. Yet we have an objection.

It seems as if nothing can be done on the Central Coast without people objecting.

Want to sink a warship for a major tourist attraction, build a skate ramp to entertain children, look for gas way out to sea, build a race track to provide a major sporting facility and generate tourism revenue or maybe just want to smarten the place up?

Well forget doing it on the Central Coast - we're the NIMBY Coast where very little gets done and what does gets objected to.

I'm certainly not in favour of laissez-faire development but all this negative whingeing is dragging the Central Coast down.

John Shingleton,

Terrigal

Brown water from tap rates poorly

I HAVE just received my new rates notice with an increase of $178 a year. Then I turned my tap on and brown water came out.

Is this what I am paying my extra rates for?

Well done Gosford Council. Can they now tell me how I am going to stretch my pension even further to cover this increase.

Marjorie Hines,

Wyoming

Shop fire doesn't stop the news

WE would like to commend Andrew and Cathy, the proprietors of the Terrigal Newsagency which was damaged by fire last week, for their magnificent efforts in keeping newspaper distribution going.

Despite losing all their facilities the newspapers kept being delivered as normal.

Thanks to the generosity of Terrigal Surf Club, they are able to continue selling papers daily.

We would encourage other residents to support them at this difficult time.

Ted and Elaine Sandeman,

urn:contentItem:4P84-PTB0-TXN5-S2YY-00000-00Pages1998-02-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisINSIDE STORYPg. 9PagesBooks

A lifetime of fiction

Monica Edwards, the British author who died last week at the age of 85, wrote two memorable series of children's books that were devoured by middle-class youngsters and approved of by their parents. Though her first two stories, 'Wish for a Pony' (1947) and 'No Mistaking Corker' (1947), were fodder for the wish-fulfilment of horsey-minded girls, their successors dealt with such adventures as forest fire, floods, smuggling, the predations of French fishermen and foot-and-mouth disease. 'Wish for a Pony' was the book Edwards liked least, and it saddened her that it was one of the most popular. But there was a depth of character in her fictional children that was missing from the huge numbers of horse-show rosette stories of the 1940s and 1950s.

It's a fair cop

The undoubted worth of Ken Sanzel's screenplay for 'The Replacement Killers' was being judged this weekend, when the movie opened in the United States. Much of his research is based on his nine years as a detective with the New York City Transit Police. Does the movie, which stars Mira Sorvino, bear any resemblance to the real-life world of crime fighting? Er, no, he says. "In police work, if you have a big event once a month, that's a lot."

Going on a bear hunt

There's a bear in there. And Piglet as well. But the problem seems to be that Christopher Robin's original toys are on the wrong side of the Atlantic. Gwyneth Dunwoody, a British MP, spotted Winnie-the-Pooh, Eeyore, Piglet and Kanga at New York's Donnell Library and decided they looked "very unhappy indeed". So she announced a campaign to bring them back to England. But New York mayor Rudolph Giuliani said, "I think Winnie-the-Pooh is an example of the very best in immigration. He's very, very proud of his background and heritage, but now he's found a new land and he's found a better life for himself here."

Comrades in arms

Bill Clinton will soon be appearing in China. Well, on bookshelves across China, anyway. 'The Los Angeles Times' reports that the Bill Clinton-Jiang Zemin story might not be nearly as titillating as some of the sagas now circulating in Washington, but the 237-page glossy paperback with smiling Presidents Clinton and Jiang on the cover is

still something of a political milestone. The book, 'Building a Constructive China-US Strategic Partnership,' makes no mention of the 29 October White House news conference in which Clinton and Jiang, who is also China's Communist Party chief, engaged in a brief, pointed debate over the bloody 1989 army crackdown in Tiananmen Square. Responding then to questions from reporters, Clinton said the Chinese Government was "on the wrong side of history" in the Tiananmen episode. The lapse is explained thus by the publisher: "If we included all the material in the book it would have been too thick".

Shop Stop

The Bookery

348 Drummond Street, Carlton 9347 7857

Age: Six years old.

Owner: Richard Hughes

Number of titles: About 12,000

The Place: Behind the anonymous green facade of the old Brunswick green cottage in Drummond Street, Carlton, is a large orderly room devoted to textbooks on English as a Second Language, Literacy, Numeracy and Linguistics - all sold under retail prices. This quiet little store supplies several of the local English language schools, TAFEs and other training courses.

For Kids: A small range of books for children on all the above subjects... except linguistics.

Special services: Publishers catalogues. Mail order. Also acts as the importer and distributor for about 12 overseas specialist publishers.

Sells videos, tapes, CD-Roms and computer software as well.

Hours: 9.30am-6pm Mon-Fri, Sat 9.30am-4pm.

Two photos.

urn:contentItem:4P8B-HBC0-TXN5-S02P-00000-00Trying too hard, the lonely, lone wolf2001-08-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Trying too hard, the lonely, lone wolfJOHN ELDER

Failing on the dance floor, unable to hold any woman in his orbit for more than a few seconds, moving in every time too soon after catching her eye, the Lone Ranger quits the lasers to walk and look in the darker places.

The darkest places are the forests of men, in places lined up two-deep as if watching a fight, focused with a sly intensity born from their longing, sad and lewd. You'd find such black forests in any nightclub doing the grind tonight, Friday night, in Melbourne.

The Lone Ranger has come to Heat, at Crown. And he isn't here to stand and look, to simply dare to dream. I spotted him 20 minutes to midnight, trying to connect at the bar. Friday night has become Saturday morning and he's still out there, trying.

In his dark suit and good shoes, playing the easy-going funny guy, the Lone Ranger does all right in the first couple of seconds; the accidental meeting of gazes, the shy but boyishly leering smile, asking if she's having a good night.

But the no-worries routine, like his dancing, is undone by a clumsy and obvious premature ejaculation of dishonorable intentions. After a long spell collecting polite mumbles and fake-smile goodbyes - and not one taker for his cheesy offer of "free drinks" - he clearly looks out of sorts. He sulks for a while, with his head down, smokes three cigarettes.

It's getting on to 2am when he puts the good-mannered make-up back on, orders two vodka coolers and walks off looking to share them with someone, preferably someone already blind.

Soon after he spots a young woman - perhaps 18 years old - walking around without a clue, her eyes glassy and puffy, her lips swollen, hair in her face, looking here and there for her friends, looking like Bambi in a forest fire.

The Lone Ranger is now at her side. She says she's looking for friends, but one of them's gone off with some guy and the other one went to the bathroom and hasn't been seen since and no, no, no, she doesn't want a drink, she just wants to find her friends.

He moves on, the drinks going warm in his hands; she lifts her head and tries to get her bearings. She nods her head when I mention last week's announcement by the Centre Against Sexual Assault that large numbers of women are being drugged at nightclubs and later sexually assaulted, a dozen of them at or after leaving the casino precinct. She nods again when I mention the story from London about the development of a swizzle stick that - working something like a pregnancy test kit - changes color if your drink has been polluted.

The problem is she just about nods at anything I have to say - until it hits her that she, too, may need to find the bathroom and that maybe her friend is still there.

It takes a while, but I find the Lone Ranger, with another blind young woman. She's a rowdier drunk than the other girl. And so he finally gets to offload that vodka soda pop, 40 minutes after leaving his spot at the bar. She gets it down in big gulps, listens to him yabbering, then moves on, leaving him looking sour - only to perk up again. And that's when he goes to the dance floor, to try something else. He's got all night, right?

Fifty per cent of complaints of sexual assault are made a week after the assault; 10-50 per cent go unreported. Drugs used to spike drinks include Rohypnol (flunitrazepam) and the bodybuilders' steroid alternative GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate). (Source: Journal of Clinical Forensic Medicine)

Photo: Boy meets girl in a nightclub. But the offer of a drink may not be a friendly gesture.

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: INDONESIA AND WORLD IMPOTENT IN THE FACE OF FIRES, CRISIS</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Bernard Estrade</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">JAKARTA, Feb 26 AFP - As its economic crisis deepens, the worsening forest fires ravaging parts of Indonesia highlight the government's failure to fulfill pledges and the international community's inability to do much about it.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The fires in remote forest areas have "escalated to an extent that made it impossible even to think of getting them under control," said the head of a German-funded fire-fighting program earlier this week.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "The only thing that could help now is rain," Integrated Forest Fire Management Project chief Ludwig Schindler added.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The fires are worrying the governments of Malaysia and Singapore, which are fearful of a repetition of the haze which last year choked whole swathes of Southeast Asia.</p><p>ASEAN environment ministers held a one-day meeting in the Malaysian city of Kuching yesterday to discuss joint measures against the fires.</p><p>Malaysian Science, Technology and Environment Minister Law Hieng Ding said the Indonesian fires had already affected parts of Sarawak state bordering East Kalimantan on the island of Borneo.</p><p> According to Schindler: "The general situation can be described with Indonesia not being able to overcome its own bureaucracy and the international community being absolutely helpless and wasting money for the sake of having done something."</p><p> While Thailand and South Korea, the other regional recipients of massive International Monetary Fund bailouts, have launched major reforms, Jakarta is backtracking on pledges made in return for its rescue money.</p><p> Its currency has lost more than 70 percent of its value and nearly all its enterprises are technically bankrupt.</p><p> Suharto, 76, who is eyeing a seventh straight five-year term as leader, is letting his administration backtrack.</p><p> Instead of implementing reforms he agreed to undertake in return for a $ US40 billion ($ A60 billion) aid package, he is clutching at supposed miraculous cure-alls such as the "currency board."</p><p> Two of his family-controlled monoplies which were to have been dissolved, have simply changed their names. He is to inaugurate this week another project  in which his eldlest daughter has a<br/> stake  that was listed among investments to be put off until the<br/> situation improved.</p><p> As happened after last November's unveiling of Indonesia's initial reform program, the international community is again worried and has sent officials to Jakarta to remind Suharto of his promises.</p><p> On the heels of the visit of German Finance Minister Theo Waigel, former US vice president Walter Mondale is to arrive here on Saturday as President Bill Clinton's special envoy.</p><p> The major fires that ravaged Indonesia from May to December last year, releasing toxic fumes across the region, caused losses worth $ US1.38 billion ($ A2.08 billion), the WorldWide Fund for Nature said yesterday.</p><p> Damage estimated at $ US1 billion ($ A1.5 billion) was sustained by Indonesia itself, 90 percent of that figure in short-term health costs, the group said in a statement issued by its Jakarta office.</p><p>Malaysia lost about $ US300 million ($ A452 million), mainly in lost industrial production and a slump in tourism as the haze spread from its bigger neighbour. Singapore lost $ US60 million ($ A90.43 million), mainly in tourism receipts.</p><p> Most of the fires, which raged out of control due amid a delayed monsoon, were deliberately started by large agro-industrial firms to clear land for oil palm plantations or quick growing trees for paper plants.</p><p> Punitive action announced to deal with the situation have not been acted upon and several firms engaged in exploiting forests, including those owned by people close to Suharto, have got back their seized licences.</p><p> Just a month after rains helped douse them, the fires have been deliberately restarted in the natural reserve forests of East Kalimantan.</p><p> "law enforcement still seems too weak and too slow to get them under control," Schindler said.</p><p>AFP  ts<br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3S3T-2S40-0048-T3VB-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="666"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4P8H-NJT0-TXN5-S091-00000-00Indonesia faces new fire threat1998-02-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisNEWSInternational NewsPg. 27Indonesia faces new fire threatLouise Williams

JAKARTA, Friday

Indonesia may be facing a new haze and forest fire disaster after the outbreak of fresh blazes in the tinder-dry forests of Kalimantan this week.

Flights were delayed by smoke haze in East Kalimantan for the first time since rains eased the region-wide haze crisis in mid-November.

Meanwhile, an Australian forestry expert has warned that past El Nino years have shown that a second round of fires usually follows the inadequate monsoon rains.

Neil Byron, deputy director of the Indonesia-based Centre for International Forestry Research, said a study of the past 200 years of forest fires and El Nino patterns in Indonesia indicated a second, and more severe, phase preceded the end of the 12-month El Nino cycle.

The Assistant Minister for the Environment, Mr Sugandhy Apandi, said: "We can assume from the meteorological information we are receiving the drought is continuing. The source of the new fires is the negligence of people clearing land and we are afraid because of the El Nino effect we will face a new disaster."

Mr Sugandhy said Kalimantan and northern Sumatra had received little rainfall, and the severe economic crisis might encourage the overuse of natural resources, using fire as a cheap method of clearing land.

A new phase of the drought, the most severe to hit Indonesia in 50 years, would also have serious implications for food supplies as most crops are expected to be harvested late and in reduced volumes.

The massive fires that raged from July to November were mainly caused by land clearing for the expansion of palm oil and timber estates and the burning off of debris from logging concessions.

Mr Sugandhy said the fires this week were deliberately lit for land clearing. Satellite images show 40 fires on a nine-kilometre front inside the Bukit Suharto preservation area and smaller fires near villages.

Mr Byron said: "The next three to four months are an absolute time bomb. During the 1982-83 El Nino year, three-quarters of the fire damage was done between January and April and these were the biggest fires ever recorded on earth."

In 1982-83 fires destroyed 3.7 million hectares of forest on Kalimantan. The fires last year destroyed an estimated 1.2 million hectares of tropical forest.

"Whenever there is an El Nino you get a dry period, which extends into October, then you get some rain which is 30 to 40 per cent of normal falls, and then the drought comes back between January and April.

"We know from Portuguese explorers' logs that there have been El Nino's in this region for at least 500 years because there are references to haze from peat swamps, but the difference now is large scale logging and plantation development."

He said land damaged by logging was eight to 10 times more likely to burn than virgin tropical forest, and fire was widely used for land clearing because it was about a quarter of the cost of any other method.

"We are still traumatised by what happened several months ago and I am very worried about lung diseases caused by the smoke," said Wiwin, a teacher in Samarinda, near the new fire zone. Another resident, Didi, said: "It hasn't rained in two months and I'm worried about the chance of the recurrence of the fires."

Photo: Fires unbeaten: A study of past El Nino years has shown that a second round of fires usually follows the inadequate monsoon rains, which will add to environmental devastation of blazes last year. Picture: REUTERS

urn:contentItem:4B7R-K000-015H-92X1-00000-00<published>2003-12-17T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:56:44Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>LETTERS TO THE EDITOR</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Watch Labor carefully</p><p nitf:lede="true"> When Prime Minister John Howard spoke at the Liberal state conference at Smithton this year, the first item of business was to restate his Government's rock solid support for Tasmania's forest industry and the Regional Forest Agreement which underpins it.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Compare that to the wishy-washy, two-bob-each-way approach of new Labor leader Mark Latham.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> After visiting Tasmania, and accepting an invitation from Bob Brown to see Tasmania's forests, Mr Latham now tells us his policy on this crucial industry for Tasmania is up in the air and under consideration!</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Watch this Labor lot carefully on the question of forests in Tasmania.</p><p>Between Jim Bacon, Paul Lennon and Mark Latham we now have multiple political strategies in place.</p><p> One thing that has become glaringly evident from Mr Latham's visit is that a vote for Labor at the next federal election opens us up to another Sydney-centric outcome last seen when Senator Richardson scuttled one billion dollars worth of pulp mill for the sake of a few lazy Sydney seats.</p><p> Forest communities beware.</p><p>Rene Hidding</p><p>Leader of the state Opposition</p><p>Launceston</p><p> I have some sympathy for arguments both for and against euthanasia, but none for the argument that we must destroy our forests to save them. The Styx, if left alone and if there is no fire, will become pure rainforest over the next 100 years or so.</p><p> If a forest fire occurs the rainforest will be removed and eucalypts will dominate.</p><p> This is a natural process of change that requires expansive areas of wild forest in which the fire/eucalypt/rainforest dynamic can occur.</p><p> Small reserves of tall forests are pointless because they become ecological islands that are ultimately unsustainable.</p><p> Logging the Styx will not regenerate the forest. Rather, a monoculture of young eucalypt trees will be established that will never be allowed to grow old enough or big enough to ever resemble the old-growth forest, either visually or biologically. The rainforest timbers will not regenerate and this resource will be lost forever, largely to fuel forestry "regeneration burns".</p><p> The Styx does not need Forestry Tasmania to regenerate it.</p><p> It has done perfectly well since the last ice age. It and forests like it just need to be left alone to remain wild, magnificent and diverse.</p><p>Erik Peacock</p><p>Berriedale</p><p> It is the people of Tasmania who own the old-growth forests managed by Forestry Tasmania.</p><p> The Bacon Government should ensure they are managed to maintain their quality and species mix to enable future generations to have the same beautiful unique timbers and healthy environment they have now.</p><p> Clearfelling, burning and regenerating for short rotation monocultures are not achieving this aim.</p><p> The RFA achieved no more than a dividing up of our forest into reserves and timber production areas, whereas the Tasmania Together process called for a change from clearfelling to ecologically sustainable selective harvesting, not a cessation of a forestry industry.</p><p>Ian Johnston</p><p>Howden</p><p>QUICK VIEWS</p><p>Tourism turn-off</p><p>Regarding the East Coast tourism development (The Mercury, December 16), might not the mountains of woodchips at Triabunna, many from magnificent ancient trees from clearfelled old-growth forests, put the tourists off?</p><p>Elizabeth Perey</p><p>Mt Stuart</p><p>Big picture</p><p>What a brilliant idea to erect a Louvre or Spanish Guggenheim on the Dunn St car park. A rival Sydney Opera House might be even better. I should love to know what our worthy Premier has to drink with his evening dinner. Is it called Mesmeric Big Picture wine?</p><p>Norman Dunbar</p><p>Sandy Bay</p><p>Too much fuss</p><p>Why all the fuss at this late stage about the bicentenary? We on Bruny Island celebrated in 1973 with the re-enactment of Captain Furneaux's landing. If Tasman had been able to come ashore it would have been 1842. About time some bowed to seniority.</p><p>J. D. Dillon</p><p>Bruny Island</p><p>Demon drink</p><p>We are in the silly season. While alcohol is associated with fun, there is often an ugly side to it. Even those in positions of political power can struggle with the side effects. Families are destroyed through it, financially and emotionally. I don't want to be a party pooper, but think before you hit the drink.</p><p>Paul Hayes</p><p>Moonah</p><p>STING IN THE TAIL</p><p>With all the shoplifting around it would pay to ask for a receipt with your Christmas present.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P6W-1CK0-TXN5-R36W-00000-00So long, sport2003-12-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisGOOD WEEKENDPg. 62So long, sportDon't get me startedJonathan Biggins

The wife and I were at a barbecue on the weekend of the World Cup semifinals and the talk was rugby from one end to the other. Finally Mrs B declared, "I think my husband must be the only man here not going to the semis."

"True," I replied. "But I am going to the Australian Dance Awards tomorrow night!"

A silence descended with the swiftness of nightfall in the Gobi desert. The clink of melting ice in the Esky suddenly sounded like icebergs shearing away from Antarctica; the barbecue like the roar of a forest fire. Men examined their beer glasses intently and five kilometres away, a dog howled.

"Er ... I'm actually presenting one of the awards," I feebly countered. "You know,

it's a part of my job type thing. It's an arts-related thing ... er ... go the Wallabies!"

Minutes later, as we walked to the car,

I reflected on the average male response

to dance. Here they are, about to spend hundreds of dollars to watch 30 strapping men from private schools spend the best part of 80 minutes with their heads up each other's backsides, yet they think ballet is gay? Please. As it turned out, the awards night was far more thrilling than watching England bore France into submission on a rain-soaked sponsor's logo in Homebush. Extraordinary displays of athleticism, invention and prowess made the England First XV look like a slightly animated showroom of fridge-freezers. One performance by the Australian Dance Theatre was so physically demanding, I felt the need to consult an orthopedic surgeon after just watching it.

Don't get me wrong, I enjoy sport, too, but every now and then I find that too much sport is more than enough - "now" being 20 hours in any given day and "then" the remaining four. On the other hand, my father can watch tennis not only until the cows come home but also until they go out again the next day. He even used to watch the qualifying rounds of the Tasmanian Open from the first ball toss to the last backhand being forced long to mercifully end the whole tawdry affair. When the networks finally stopped broadcasting

it, they discovered he was the only viewer.

At Newcastle Boys High, sport was compulsory, a practice since banned by the UN on humanitarian grounds. Every boy had to enter at least one event in the athletics carnival, so I chose shotput. Immediately disqualified after my first throw, I had nonetheless entered and could repair to the canteen. The same draconian regime applied to the swimming carnival, where you had to enter at least one race - even if you couldn't swim. I wasn't a bad swimmer so it wasn't such an ordeal, although I was never fond of presenting my puny physique to the school's gaze as the PE teachers chipped the ice off the pool's surface. At least I didn't come last or sink to the bottom, like a few of the more stoutly chaps, from whence they were rescued by clutching onto the leaf skimmer.

I quickly realised it was the sort of school that didn't like people who used the term whence, so in second year I entered the javelin as well and did cross-country running because some idiot told me it was a mind game, before settling on tennis because (being a lefty) I had a decent serve out wide to the advantage court.

Ironically, my only major physical injury has come not through sporting endeavour but dancing. At the end of a long tour of a show, I was standing in the wings preparing for

a sketch - every sport of the 26th Olympiad presented as interpretative jazz ballet to the music of Cats. My how they laughed! The cue came and as I lifted onto my toes to spring gazelle-like onto the stage, my leg exploded with pain as if someone had hit me in the back of the calf with a cricket bat. Despite being unable to support my own weight,

I struggled through the routine, although admittedly the audience was puzzled by

the sight of a grown man in a flared Lycra unitard in obvious agony, limping heavily and falling over repeatedly. When the curtain came down, I was whisked off to casualty and spent the next two weeks on crutches. But I didn't miss a show - I was back on the horse (metaphorically) the next night. So cop that, you big girly rugger-bugger sissy-Marys!
