urn:contentItem:7WDS-S841-2RR2-D02V-00000-00Fire prevention on backburner2009-08-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESOpinionPg. 17Fire prevention on backburnerMiranda Devine

You would have thought, with less than 10 weeks until the bushfire season, this week's Victorian bushfires royal commission interim report might have mentioned the most frequently raised concern in submissions, the one which experts say determines whether a manageable blaze becomes an inferno: the availability of fuel.

But no. Not one of the report's 51 recommendations deals with prescribed or controlled burning or any means of fuel reduction which reduces the intensity of a fire and makes firefighting easier, or even possible.

That is despite the fact 485 of more than 1200 submissions concern fuel reduction.

The commission, which has spent four months investigating the February 7 fires which killed 173 people, claims to have first dealt with issues relevant to this bushfire season and will address long-term changes before handing down its final report in July. But in a press release flagging future areas of interest, the commission makes no mention of fuel reduction, just building standards, bunkers, the electricity industry, and "a range of other matters".

The Orwellian language of the interim report, which rebadges "evacuation" as "relocation", hardly engenders confidence that people will be any safer in bushfire seasons to come.

To be fair, it may be that the commission is not copping out but buying time before tackling the controversial problem of fuel reduction and management of public land.

There is no shortage of insightful material in the submissions waiting to be addressed. The submission from the Institute of Foresters of Australia, for instance, is crisp, clear, informative and unemotional.

It charts the evolution of the "deeply unsatisfactory" bushfire situation in Victoria, especially over the past decade when there has been "a political focus on expanding national parks and conservation reserves" - now 52 per cent of Victoria's public lands.

There has been "a profound change in management focus to meet more passive conservation aims [leading] to a loss of fire management expertise, greater restrictions to public access due to track closures and declining levels of maintenance, and a demonstrable reduction in the broadscale use of prescribed fire as a management tool to mitigate the impact of summer bushfires.

"This combination of factors has allowed forest fuels to accumulate to an extent that has raised the intensity of summer bushfires and increasingly forced a greater reliance on emergency fire-fighting," the institute says.

"This has occurred at a time when there has been an increasing development of housing in bushfire-prone areas both making the use of prescribed burning more difficult on adjacent public lands..."

These professional foresters not only have university training in bushfire behaviour, fire suppression and prevention, and land use planning, but every day they are in the field working in forest, parks and plantation management roles, fighting fires and using prescribed burning to mitigate fire. As they put it: "We know the business, from the sharp end."

Their submission points out that south-east Australia's flammable native forests and climate make it one of the most fire-prone areas in the world. Bushfires are inevitable, with "high-intensity conflagrations every few years when dry fuels and rainfall deficits combine with days of high temperature and wind. This has been the case throughout our recorded history."

Refusing to perform adequate controlled burning in fire-prone landscapes "inevitably results in heavy fuel accumulations that consign forests to a regime of periodic large, high intensity fire."

The foresters trace the history of fire politics from the 1920s when European ideas started subverting the Australian forestry practice of regularly using fire to "clean up" the forest floor and maintain a light fuel load as the "key to controlling bushfires".

Controlled burning during this period was haphazard. Then in 1939 came the Black Friday inferno which killed 71 Victorians.

Paradoxically, say the foresters, "these fires heralded the beginning of a new era of forest fire management" after the Stretton royal commission placing the blame squarely on "the hand of man", on poor land management and inadequate controlled burning.

Stretton's legacy was that Australian forestry moved to controlled burning rather than bushfire suppression to protect its forests. Foresters were responsible for almost all the state's forests and there was a "healthy balance between expenditure on fire prevention activities in the off season against that spent on summer bushfire suppression".

But the 1982 election of the Cain government in Victoria "signalled the start of an enduring period of profound change which continues today".

Successive state governments "largely embraced the environmentalists' view that Victoria's forests needed to be 'saved' and that this would be achieved simply by changing public land tenure from state forest to national park".

National Parks in Victoria increased by almost 30 per cent from 1998 to 2008. "A substantial part of this expansion has had little or no rational conservation-based foundation, and has been undertaken simply to serve a political need to win the support of 'green' voters."

The upshot is that fire mitigation activities, such as controlled fuel reduction burning, have been neglected in favour of "funding towards an emergency bushfire suppression model that we believe will always fail to justify its huge expense".

Suppression is nigh on impossible with high intensity fires "that are a direct consequence of inadequate fire prevention activities which over many years have allowed forest fuels to accumulate to high levels in much of the forest estate".

This week's interim report has drawn criticism because it didn't identify scapegoats to crucify. Clearly mistakes were made that terrible day, but the fires were out of control, a perfect storm of weather and fuel loads pushing them at a speed and intensity that could not be stopped.

It was an impossible situation that should have been avoided. Prevention is always better than cure.

devinemiranda@hotmail.com

ILLUSTRATION: Ed Aragon

urn:contentItem:3SJJ-4W00-0048-T2JP-00000-00<published>1997-09-17T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:56:44Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Features</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>PAC: FORMER PNG FOOD BOWL FACES STARVATION</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Paul Ruffini, Papua New Guinea Correspondent</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"> TAMBUL, PNG, Sept 17 AAP - The once-lush Tambul valley in Papua New Guinea's Western Highlands is normally considered a food bowl - but now 11,000 villagers are facing starvation even if rain comes to the parched hills within a month.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The mountain farmers who usually produce kaukau (sweet potato), cabbages, carrots and potatoes in abundance have nowhere to go.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Famine surrounds them - at Kandep to the west, Mendi to the south and Hagen region to the east.</p><p>In previous hard times they have migrated to neighbouring provinces and survived on handouts from family and friends. This time they have no choice.</p><p> "The only situation left for the people is to starve to death," said farmer Martin Bai examining his bare garden.</p><p> "Areas where we normally migrate to are also affected now like Hagen, Wabag and Mendi."</p><p> The Tambul-Nebiliyer region tucked in the Western Highlands' south-western corner is one of the areas hardest-hit by the nationwide drought.</p><p> Continuing frosts have meant double trouble for the highlanders, killing what's left of their drought-ravaged crops.</p><p> The shrubs, casuarina, fir and banana trees that cover the mountains around Tambul are now drying to a copper colour.</p><p> A smoke haze blots out the sun as a massive forest fire sweeps up from Mt Giluwe to the south and smaller blazes rage through the mountains.</p><p> Rivers like Amboga near the Tambul township have fallen two metres over the last four months. Mountain streams, usually the source of water for drinking and cooking, are running at a trickle.</p><p> The black soil of the food gardens is now bare, with the exception of small patches of frost-burned cabbage and withered kaukau plants.</p><p> Douglas Lingawa, the district administrator, remembers the last major drought in 1972 when the Australians came to the rescue of the villagers.</p><p> Sacks of rice and cartons of tinned food were air-dropped onto old tyres and piles of dried grass in the village clearing.</p><p> Village chief Napa Nambo, now in his 80s, said the current drought and frost were the worst in living memory.</p><p> "This is the worst one I've experienced and we are looking at a disaster," he said.</p><p> "People are actually feeling the pinch of looking for food and they are starving now."</p><p> Mr Lingawa said the drought was the worst in 50 years. He said there was no starvation yet, but the food supply would not last much longer.</p><p> "Food is left, but it's not that sufficient to hold a population ...," he said.</p><p> "According to my predictions it would last for a month or so."</p><p> The Papua New Guinea government has so far contributed $ A22.8 million to drought and frost relief nationwide. Prime Minister Bill Skate has also promised $ A9.5 million in poverty alleviation next year.</p><p> Mr Lingawa is already seeing the social impact of the drought. Thirty schools in the Tambul-Nebiliyer region have been closed due to lack of water.</p><p> While there have been no deaths directly attributable to the situation, there has been an increase in dysentery and typhoid, particularly among children, he said.</p><p> He blamed the increase on sanitation problems caused by the lack of water.</p><p> Farmer Bai said even if the rains came within the next two months it would take a year before the sweet potato crops, which are the staple food source, were re-established.</p><p> "The rehabilitation process will take time," he said.</p><p> "Even if we have the planting when we have rain, the first harvest will be around September next year."</p><p> Without food drops and seedlings for replanting he does not know how his people will survive.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1997</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SJJ-4W00-0048-T2JP-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="599"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1997 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4B4G-H3S0-015G-P2JS-00000-00<published>2003-12-02T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:56:44Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES-COLUMN- ARTS; Pg. 15</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Golf and guitars, with just a hint of the commotions</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Iain Shedden</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">As his tour tees off, a mellow Lloyd Cole talks to Iain Shedden</p><p nitf:lede="true">IF you want to talk music with Lloyd Cole, don't mention golf. If you do, chances are the English-born, Massachusetts-based songwriter's passion for the game will dominate the conversation.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> For instance, he seems as eager to play some of Australia's best courses in the next few weeks as he is about his solo tour, which begins in Melbourne on Thursday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Three years after his last visit, Cole, who plays off a seven handicap, has brought his clubs as well as his guitar and plans to make good use of both.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>"Actually golf doesn't take up enough of my time," he says, revealing even more his love for the sport. Such is his dedication that he plans to play in the Massachusetts Amateur Championships next year.</p><p> To some it might seem an idyllic lifestyle, travelling the world hitting a few balls between shows. However, Cole fans will be more concerned with hearing him play songs from his fifth solo album, Music in a Foreign Language, than about the putt he sank on the 18th.</p><p> If they're lucky they will also hear highlights from his more illustrious period in the 1980s, when, with his band the Commotions, he scored hits such as Perfect Skin, Forest Fire and Brand New Friend.</p><p> Cole's blend of jangly pop tunes and English-lit sophistication was a refreshing antidote to the superficial pop alternatives of the time, but the band's reign lasted only five years before Cole upped sticks to New York and embarked on a solo career. That career has taken on a more folky, singer-songwriter hue.</p><p> What triggered his reinvention, he explains, was a folk festival he played in Belgium. "It wasn't something I was used to but I immediately felt comfortable," he says. "And the amazing thing is that folk people are a lot cooler than rock ones. Joan Baez is one of the coolest people I've ever met."</p><p> These days, Cole, 42, operates on a much smaller scale than in his '80s heyday, when in Australia he played to crowds of up to 25,000, but he has maintained a core audience through albums such as Don't Get Weird on Me, Babe (1991), Bad Vibes (1993) and Love Story (1995).</p><p> "I became a one-man band to get myself back on my feet," he says, "and I'm just about back on my feet now."</p><p> Cole's retreat to New York was brought about partly by the pressures of being a rock star. He says he regrets that at their peak he and the Commotions "didn't have the time to enjoy it. We were trying to be like Talking Heads or something like that and it didn't make us happy. Mind you, Talking Heads weren't a happy band either."</p><p> Time can heal old wounds, of course, and there are rumours that the Commotions will reconvene to celebrate their 20th anniversary next year.</p><p> "There are rumblings that we might drag ourselves out of the cobwebs to do a tour," Cole says.</p><p> "Nothing is confirmed yet but we might do it if our combined beer bellies aren't too big to go on the road together. We've all emailed each other and nobody has actually said absolutely no. It could be exciting. These kinds of things, if you get it right it can be great, but if you get it wrong it could be awful."</p><p> Commotions or not, Cole appears to be happy with his lot. He moved recently from New York to a small town three hours away in Massachusetts. He prefers the quiet lifestyle there with his wife and two sons and he runs his professional life -- writing songs, booking studios, maintaining his website -- from a small office.</p><p> "I have my golf clubs collection in one corner and my wife has a bit of an office in the other and my computer's in the middle," he says.</p><p> His computer also features as a golf aid. Some of his Australian golf matches were prompted by invites directed to his website.</p><p> "I have tee times booked all over the place," he says eagerly.</p><p> Despite appearances to the contrary, not all of Cole's down time on this trip will be dedicated to golf. On December 10 he will address students at Griffith University on the Gold Coast on the nature of popular music.</p><p>Cole's Australian tour begins in Melbourne on Thursday and travels to Canberra, Byron Bay, Brisbane, Sydney, Adelaide and Fremantle.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P85-12S0-TXN5-R1S5-00000-00Soeharto told to account for disasters1997-10-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESInternational NewsPg. 8Soeharto told to account for disasters* Rupiah collapse * Smoke crisis * CorruptionLouise Williams Herald Correspondent

Jakarta: The Soeharto Government was facing an unprecedented crisis last night as a wave of public criticism over its handling of the fire emergency coincided with a dramatic fall in the rupiah and warnings of serious economic problems ahead.

The Environment Minister, Mr Sarwono Kusumaatmadja, pushed the urgency of the forest fire and smog crisis to a new level yesterday, saying: "If we do not change our ways, we will not survive as a nation."

Soon after, President Soeharto called an emergency meeting of economic ministers after the Central Bank intervened to save the sliding rupiah, which lost almost 5 per cent in morning trading.

More than 50 per cent has been wiped off the value of the Indonesian currency in less than two months.

At the same time yesterday, Indonesia's biggest Islamic organisations called on the Government to act more decisively in dealing with the forest fires, and to look at the corruption and collusion behind the burning off of large tracts of land despite

warnings of the coming drought. The leader of the 28-million strong Muhammadiyah, Mr Amien Rais, said the fires, drought, economic crisis and fatal accidents of the past few months were a warning to both the Government and the community to "repent".

In a statement signed by religious leaders, Mr Rais said: "We are calling on the Government to remember that power is a mandate from Allah that has to be accounted for. No matter how great and strong a power is, Allah will one day take it back."

The biggest disaster facing Indonesia was the complacency and arrogance of those in power, he said.

Government ministers responsible for the recentdisasters should resign and the Soeharto Government had to face the problems of corruption and collusion in its ownranks.

Mr Sarwono said Indonesia had no choice but to change its land-use policies, end slash and burn practices and the stop the abuse of political connections to flout environmental regulations.

Asked whether he was concerned that a repeat of this year's haze could threaten the Commonwealth Games in Kuala Lumpur next year, he said: "Of course, we are very concerned. It is my job to stop the haze. If it happens all over again next year we are out of business as a nation."

Mr Sarwono was speaking at an extraordinary briefing for journalists by seven Indonesian ministers dealing with the fire crisis, in an attempt to arrest the damage to Indonesia's international image the haze crisis is causing.

Fire-fighting teams had put out scores of fires, he said, but fires burning in peat seams in Sumatra and Kalimantan would be difficult to extinguish and could burn for months.

On the economic front, the Central Bank moved in to halt the collapse of the rupiah yesterday morning when the currency fell to an all-time low of 3,855 to the US dollar, a loss of more than 50 per cent since mid-August.

The stock market also lost ground as brokers and economists predicted the rupiah could fall to the 4,000 mark, leaving scores of major Indonesian companies critically exposed on large US dollar debts.

There would be a certain economic slow-down and the prospect of politically sensitive inflation and unemployment as crop failures due to the drought coincided with the corporate financial crisis.

Illus: An Indonesian family geared up to deal with smoke in Jambi, Sumatra. Hundreds of Indonesian forest fires have cast a haze across south-east Asia. Photo by REUTER/JASON REED

urn:contentItem:4585-6YV0-0197-F51R-00000-00<published>1997-09-18T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:56:44Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Farmers starve as drought hits PNG food bowl</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>RUFFINI P</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE once-lush Tambul valley in Papua New Guinea's Western Highlands is normally considered a food bowl _ but now 11,000 villagers are facing starvation even if rain comes to the parched hills within a month.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The mountain farmers who usually produce kaukau (sweet potato), cabbages, carrots and potatoes in abundance have nowhere to go.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Famine surrounds them _ at Kandep to the west, Mendi to the south and Hagen region to the east.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>In previous hard times they have migrated to neighbouring provinces and survived on handouts from family and friends. This time they have no choice.</p><p>"The only situation left for the people is to starve to death," farmer Martin Bai said while examining his barren garden.</p><p>"Areas where we normally migrate to are also affected now like Hagen, Wabag and Mendi."</p><p>The Tambul-Nebiliyer region, tucked in the Western Highlands' south-western corner, is one of the areas hardest hit by the nationwide drought.</p><p>Continuing frosts have meant double trouble for the highlanders, killing what is left of their drought-ravaged crops.</p><p>The shrubs, casuarina, fir and banana trees which cover the mountains around Tambul are drying to a copper colour.</p><p>A smoke haze blots out the sun as a massive forest fire sweeps up from Mt Giluwe to the south and smaller blazes rage through the mountains.</p><p>Rivers, such as Amboga near the Tambul township, have fallen two metres over the past four months. Mountain streams, usually the source of water for drinking and cooking, are running at a trickle.</p><p>The black soil of the food gardens is now bare, with the exception of small patches of frost-burned cabbage and withered kaukau plants.</p><p>Douglas Lingawa, the district administrator, remembers the last major drought in 1972 when Australians came to the rescue of the villagers.</p><p>Sacks of rice and cartons of tinned food were air-dropped on to old tyres and piles of dried grass in the village clearing.</p><p>Village chief Napa Nambo, now in his 80s, said the current drought and frost were the worst in living memory.</p><p>"This is the worst one I've experienced and we are looking at a disaster," he said.</p><p>"People are actually feeling the pinch of looking for food and they are starving now."</p><p>Mr Lingawa said the drought was the worst in 50 years. He said there was no starvation yet, but the food supply would not last much longer.</p><p>"Food is left, but it's not that sufficient to hold a population," he said.</p><p>"According to my predictions, it would last for a month or so."</p><p>The Papua New Guinea Government so far has contributed $A22.8 million to drought and frost relief nationwide. Prime Minister Bill Skate also has promised $A9.5 million in poverty alleviation next year.</p><p>Mr Lingawa is already seeing the social impact of the drought. Thirty schools in the Tambul-Nebiliyer region have been closed because of a lack of water.</p><p>While there have been no deaths directly attributable to the situation, there has been an increase in dysentery and typhoid, particularly among children, he said.</p><p>He blamed the increase on sanitation problems caused by the lack of water.</p><p>Farmer Bai said even if the rains came within the next two months, it would take a year before the sweet potato crops, which are the staple food source, were re-established.</p><p>"The rehabilitation process will take time," he said.</p><p>"Even if we have the planting when we have rain, the first harvest will be around September next year."</p><p>Without food drops and seedlings for replanting, he does not know how his people will survive.</p><p>Australian Associated Press</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P8H-NRD0-TXN5-S198-00000-00Serious smoke1997-10-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisTRAVELPg. 2Serious smoketraveller's CHECKCLIVE DORMAN

Travel to South-East Asia has been decimated by the forest fires raging in Indonesia, with the Foreign Affairs Department now advising Australians that travel could involve serious health risks. Among the popular destinations in the region for Australians, only Bali remains unaffected.

The department this week discounted Australian press reports that Bali had been blanketed by smoke as a result of a "forest fire" out of control on the neighboring island of Lombok. The department says a grass fire on Lombok was put out by local authorities on Tuesday and, by Wednesday, Bali's skies were clear.

But Bali is about the only place in Indonesia where there's a blue sky. Plantation fires - believed deliberately lit by big-business operators clearing forest land - are out of control from Irian Jaya, on New Guinea island, to western Sumatra, 5000 kilometres away.

They have made travel in Indonesia outside Bali hazardous and uncertain. Domestic airline flights have been disrupted and several smaller regional airports, in both Indonesia and neighboring Malaysia, have been closed for varying periods.

In light of last Friday's air disaster in Sumatra, when a Garuda Airbus A300 crashed, killing 234 people, it is clear that flying the domestic airways in Indonesia is now more potentially dangerous than it already was. Though the Garuda crash may have been the result of confusion between the crew and air-traffic controllers, it probably would not have happened had thick smoke not been blanketing the area.

In Canberra, the Department of Foreign Affairs is taking about 600 calls a day from would-be travellers trying to find out which destinations are affected. The number to call is (02) 261 3305. There's also an Internet site at www.dfat.gov.au

By mid-week, the smoke haze was affecting almost every country in South-East Asia:

* THAILAND: the pall of smoke from Sumatra had begun moving into southern Thailand, and was beginning to affect resort towns, such as Phuket and Koh Samui. Rain this week cleared the air in Phuket but the Department of Foreign Affairs warned that this was only temporary and the area was expected to be increasingly affected.

* MALAYSIA: Kuala Lumpur airport this week became the first major airport in the region to be forced to close, shutting for an hour early Tuesday morning. Visibility in Kuala Lumpur at times has been down to a few metres.

With fires raging out of control on Borneo island, the Malaysian states of Sabah and Sarawak were also virtually off-limits to travellers, with Brunei also badly affected.

* SINGAPORE: Badly affected, though many of the thousands of Australians going there each week are only passing through on their way to somewhere else and can bunker down, while waiting for their connecting flights, in the air-conditioning at Changi Airport. So far, flight operations at Changi haven't been seriously affected.

* INDONESIA: Sumatra - forget it. Virtually the whole island is enveloped by the smoke, which means that some of Indonesia's most beautiful destinations, such as Lake Toba in central Sumatra, can't be reached.

The haze is floating east as far as western Java, which means the capital, Jakarta, is another major city badly affected. Smoke was also hanging over Irian Jaya, extending west to some of the islands between Bali and Irian Jaya, though these areas are well off the beaten track for Western tourists.

* PHILIPPINES: Most of the Philippines have escaped the worst of the haze, though there were reports this week that the south-west of the country, including the city of Zamboanga on Davao Island, were now being affected. By mid-week, the Department of Foreign Affairs hadn't been able to verify these reports.

Write to: Clive Dorman, Traveller's Check, The Age, 250 Spencer Street, Melbourne 3000, or fax (03) 9601 2332.

urn:contentItem:3SJJ-4N10-0048-T52S-00000-00<published>1997-09-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:56:44Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>WORLD NEWS IN BRIEF</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">SAUDI BEHEAD</p><p nitf:lede="true"> RIYADH, Sept 29 AFP - A Saudi convicted of murder and a Pakistani found guilty of drug trafficking were executed by sword today in Riyadh, the interior ministry said Monday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The two executions bring to 110 the number of people executed this year in Saudi Arabia, which follows a strict version of Islamic law.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Convicted murders, rapists, drug offenders, and armed robbers face the death penalty under Saudi law.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> In 1996, a total of 68 executions were announced, down from a record 191 the year before.</p><p>AFP</p><p> US FIRES</p><p> LOS ANGELES, Sept 29 AFP - Some one thousand firefighters battled a northern California forest fire today that destroyed about 80 homes and forced several hundred people to evacuate.</p><p> The California Department of Forestry said it hoped that the fire, which burned up about 2,300 hectares of forest north of Sacramento, the state capital, would be under control by tomorrow.</p><p> The spread of the blaze was helped by a drought that has been affecting California for several months.</p><p>AFP</p><p> US BLAZE</p><p>ARCHER, Idaho, Sept 29 AP - Six children died in an early morning trailer fire in Archer, Idaho while four others were able to escape to safety after one of them knocked out a window.</p><p> The remains of four children were found Saturday.</p><p> Craig Peterson, special agent in charge of the state Criminal Investigation Bureau in Idaho Falls, said the ages of the victims are between 5 and 10.</p><p>AP</p><p>JAPAN PASSENGER</p><p> TOKYO, Sept 29 AFP - A British Airways jumbo jet bound for London returned to Narita airport, east of Tokyo, today after an Egyptian passenger turned violent, airline officials said.</p><p> The plane with 346 passengers and crew members aboard decided to turn back while it was flying over the Sea of Japan as the 43-year-old Egyptian man was acting violently, the officials said.</p><p> The aircraft returned to the airport around 4:20 pm (1720 AEST), about one hour and 20 minutes after it notified the Narita office of the transport ministry via radio of its intention to turn back to the airport.</p><p> The passenger, who had become emotionally unstable and was shouting, was sent to a hospital, Kyodo News said.</p><p>AFP</p><p>FRANCE ACCIDENT</p><p> PARIS, Sept 29 DPA - At least nine people died in a mass pile-up on a motorway in the French Normandy province near Bourg-Achard today, police said.</p><p> Some 40 vehicles including trucks and buses were involved in the accident.</p><p> The accident happened in thick fog on the route between Rouen and Le Havre.</p><p> There were conflicting reports on the number of people injured, the motorway was closed for several hours and authorities declared a catastrophe alert.</p><p> DPA</p><p> TIMOR EMBASSY</p><p> LISBON, Sept 29 AFP - Six East Timorese who took refuge in the Austrian embassy in Jakarta 10 days ago were still holed up in the mission today despite efforts to have them flown to Portugal, the LUSA news agency reported.</p><p>Austrian ambassador Victor Segala, contacted by the agency from Lisbon, said the six, including two young girls under the age of 10, were in good health and that embassy employees visited them three times a day.</p><p> Since September 1993 more than 130 East Timorese have sought refuge in various embassies in the Indonesian capital before leaving for Portugal via the Netherlands.</p><p>AFP</p><p>INDIA RITUAL</p><p> NEW DELHI, Sept 29 AFP - Police arrested six men for allegedly trying to bury a boy alive in a religious ritual in northern India, the Press Trust of India reported today.</p><p> It said the suspects tried to murder the 13-year-old boy on Friday near a northern Indian bird sanctuary.</p><p> Local residents seeing eight men trying to bury the unnamed boy in a religious ritual, overpowered four of them, the police said, adding that two other alleged attackers were arrested later.</p><p>AFP</p><p> ENDS WORLD DATELINES    <br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1997</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SJJ-4N10-0048-T52S-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="645"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1997 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4H7V-HG70-015H-90M2-00000-00<published>2005-09-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:56:44Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Selling life on Mars</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>BRIAN BERGSTEIN</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">ALL companies set goals but the newly formed 4Frontiers Corp is eyeing some expansive horizons. The company's mission: to open a small human settlement on Mars within 20 years or so.</p><p nitf:lede="true">It may sound far-fetched. The company's initial plans are a lot more terrestrial, such as developing a 2250m2 replica of a Mars settlement on Earth, then charging tourists admission. But the people behind the venture are quite serious, as serious as the $A33 million they want to raise from investors.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>AP</p></bodyText></section><p>CEO Mark Homnick, a former manager for Intel Corp who has registered 4Frontiers in Florida, says he has already raised "a couple million" from people he won't name. He hopes for an initial public offering within five years.</p><p>That still leaves a lot of questions: Why should people live on Mars? If it's going to be done, should a private enterprise engage in what would be one of humanity's defining moments? Besides, what's in it for investors?</p><p>Homnick and his co-founders -- a long-time Mars aficionado named Bruce Mackenzie and a 25-year-old Massachusetts Institute of Technology masters student, Joseph Palaia -- are ready with several answers.</p><p>First, they contend, humans need a new frontier to explore, with all the intellectual and engineering challenges that creating a home on Mars would present. Also, who knows the fate of Earth? Will we meet an early end at the hands of an asteroid or from warfare, disease or some other catastrophe?</p><p>In that case, we'd be glad civilisation had been preserved by some colonists on Mars and perhaps elsewhere in the galaxy, if all goes well on the red planet. That broader vision of space settlement gives 4Frontiers its name: the frontiers being the Earth, the moon, Mars and the asteroids.</p><p>"It's the nature of life -- life tries to expand and tries to adapt," said Mackenzie. "If there's a forest fire in one valley, then all of the organisms in the next valley will slowly creep over the ridge and repopulate that valley. Any species that don't do it eventually die out."</p><p>Going to space, he believes, is as if "all of Earth's life, acting together, is trying to get into the next valley". "And the only way we can do it is by building rockets."</p><p>Mackenzie, a software developer, has devoted much of his energy to a non-profit group called the Mars Foundation, which aims to advance knowledge about how to colonise the planet. But he decided a private venture such as 4Frontiers also would be necessary to drive things forward.</p><p>Although US President George W. Bush has called for a manned mission to Mars, Mackenzie believes big bureaucracies might never get the job done right.</p><p>"It's better to have lots of groups out there, all trying things," Mackenzie said.</p><p>Space is no longer solely the province of earnest astronauts with crew cuts and government-issued uniforms. Space tourism is on the verge of becoming big business. Space Adventures Ltd of Arlington, Virginia, has brokered $A26 million trips for the wealthy on Russian rockets and is taking deposits for $131 million fly-bys of the far side of the moon. For a lot less money, you can sign up for a quick blast into zero gravity.</p><p>In comparison, 4Frontiers' ultimate goal of an extended stay on Mars is extreme.</p><p>It would take months to get there. Once there, you couldn't kick off your shoes and dig your toes into the sand. Life would transpire in an enclosed space with pumped-in air (unless Martian settlers could pull off the even more speculative feat of "terraforming" the planet by changing its toxic atmosphere). Venturing outside would require sealed suits.</p><p>To begin, 4Frontiers plans to gather patents and engineering ideas that would enable a small crew to land on Mars with home-building materials and the manufacturing capability to keep expanding the settlement. The key would be to find ways to miniaturise industrial processes, such as making plastic or steel, and methods for exploiting Martian resources, such as the carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, iron in the dirt or the water bound up in Martian ice.</p><p>As the company gains expertise, it expects to sell consulting services to aerospace companies or NASA. It envisions getting work designing Mars sets for movies and Mars rides for amusement parks. Meanwhile, it plans to construct a mock-up of its Mars home and begin selling tickets to it by 2007. Possible sites in Colorado, Florida and New Mexico are being considered.</p><p>A business plan estimates these projects would bring in $A44 million in revenue in 2010.</p><p>Even if that flies, then what? A $44 million company probably isn't in a great position to begin launching rockets. Homnick says 4Frontiers would probably "stay incremental" through the early 2010s, perhaps getting involved in robotic surveys of Mars or asteroid mining.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4T01-SX50-TXN5-S146-00000-00Loan crisis sinks US bank2008-07-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 20Loan crisis sinks US bankPeter Weekes, Business Editor with New York Times, Washington Post, Bloomberg

US MORTGAGE lender IndyMac Bancorp has become the largest retail bank to fall victim to the American mortgage crisis.

The Federal Deposit Insur ance Corporation, which regulates the sector, took control of the California-based bank after it was left short of cash by a run of depositors.

It is estimated IndyMac's failure after Wall Street closed on Friday will cost the insurance fund between $US4 billion ($A4.1 billion) and $US8 billion after the bank racked up almost $US900 million in losses due to America's worst housing crisis since the Great Depression.

"This is a flare-up in the financial forest fire that is far beyond anything we've seen before," said Christopher Low, chief economist at New York investment firm FTN Financial.

And it is triggering worries that would have been unthinkable even a year ago - including that the US Treasury's debt might lose its AAA credit grade because of heavy blows to the nation's financial health from the housing mess.

Four months ago, many on Wall Street believed they had seen the worst of the credit crisis rooted in the housing market's woes. The March collapse of brokerage Bear Stearns, a key player in the business of packaging dicey loans for sale to investors, was the kind of high-profile calamity that historically has marked the end of financial crises.

"It's all part of the whole unravelling of global credit markets," said Johnathan Pain of HFA Asset Management.

"What I am hearing is the FDIC is ringing up retired staff and asking them to come back to work because they are expecting a huge number of bank failures this year and there aren't enough regulators."

The collapse of IndyMac follows a recent warning by Jamie Dimon, chief executive of JP Morgan Chase, that credit markets could deteriorate further and even Wall Street investment banks should not be considered too big to fail.

Australian banks also face problems, with CBA and St George last week raising rates to cover the cost of funds and NAB saying further provisions may be needed on top of the $US1.1 billion it has already set aside for collateral debt obligations.

Since the subprime crisis emerged in the US late last year, about $US400 billion in loans have been written off globally, and leading market players are now predicting the final figure could pass $US1 trillion.

"The subprime virus has grown and mutated," Mr Pain said.

"It started in the US, then crossed the Atlantic and hit Ireland, hit the UK and hit Spain. It then travelled across the world and hit New Zealand. There is no way Australia is not going to get hit."

Before Wall Street closed on Friday night, panicked investors pushed US mortgage finance giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to the brink as concerns emerged that rising defaults would drain their reserves and force a government takeover.

The two government-chartered, shareholder-owned giants underpin some $US5 trillion in home loans, or about one in every two US mortgages.

The Dow Jones fell sharply during Friday's session until Reuters reported (later withdrawn) that Freddie Mac would make use of the discount lending window that allowed many institutional banks to survive the first round of the credit crunch.

Charles Schwab & Co analyst Brad Sorenson said the companies "affect a much wider swathe of the economy than just a typical financial institution, such as Bear Stearns", and that any hint of failure would be "devastating to the US and indeed the global, financial markets".

Fears that either of the mortgage giants would require a government bailout crossed the Atlantic to help drive the British sharemarket into bear territory.

Declines in the value of Britain's top 100 companies reached more than 20% since their peak, heralding sustained selling not seen since the stockmarket collapse of 2003.

"The movement . . . was a clear indication that we haven't reached the bottom and the bears are still fully in control," said Angus Campbell, head of sales at British-based Capital Spreads.

AMP Capital Investors chief economist Shane Oliver said the Australian market was likely to open up to 100 points lower as news of IndyMac's collapse dragged down financial stocks. He also said resource stocks could eventually get hit as economic growth of the commodity-hungry developing world slowed, taking the shine off recent record coal and iron ore prices.

IndyMac, America's second-biggest independent mortgage bank, with $US32 billion of assets, is the second-biggest bank to go under, after Continental Illinois National Bank & Trust - with $US40 billion of assets - in 1984.

IndyMac is the fifth US bank to fail this year. -- With NEW YORK TIMES, WASHINGTON POST, BLOOMBERG

Another one bites the dust

· IndyMac was America's second-largest independent mortgage provider.

· It is the fifth US bank to fail this year.

· It will cost up to $US8 billion to revive the retail bank as a new government entity.

· It racked up almost $900 million in losses as house prices tumbled.

· Concerns about mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac weighed heavily on Wall Street during Friday trade and drove the FTSE into official bear territory.

· About $US400 billion in loans have been written off since the subprime crisis emerged in the US late last year. Some say the figure could hit $US1 trillion.

urn:contentItem:457Y-MH30-0197-51H7-00000-00<published>1997-09-26T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:56:44Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 6</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Bank chief offers funding in Asian haze catastrophe </nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE choking haze engulfing South-East Asia drew international attention yesterday, with World Bank chief James Wolfensohn saying his institution was ready to help deal with the "tragic" problem, while the head of the World Wide Fund for Nature described the thick pall of smoke as an "international catastrophe". Addressing a news conference on the sidelines of the IMFWorld Bank annual meeting in Hong Kong, Mr Wolfensohn said: "We are ready to come in in any way on an emergency basis if funding were the reason for the problem."</p><p nitf:lede="true"> He said the haze, blamed on farmers felling and burning trees to cultivate their land in Indonesia, was "terrible", "tragic" and "dreadful". "We are ready to come in with money if it is necessary, but money does not appear to be a problem. The problem appears to be a physical problem -putting this damn thing out," he said.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>AFP, Reuters, The Times </p></bodyText></section><p>Fires in Indonesia, partly blamed on drought but mostly on land clearing by burning, have belched out a smog that has triggered health alerts across Malaysia, Singapore, The Philippines, Brunei and southern Thailand.</p><p> In Jakarta, WWFN chief Dr Syed Babar Ali told reporters the scale of the fires "is so big it is an international catastrophe going well beyond the borders of Indonesia". But he admitted experts were at a loss.</p><p> "The question is how to put it out and the answer is we don't know," he said.</p><p>Indonesian government officials said President Suharto had described the haze as a national disaster and urged that efforts be stepped up to extinguish the fires.</p><p> Sources in Jakarta, citing satellite photographs, said between 600,000 and 800,000 hectares of Indonesia forest and plantation had been hit by the fires.</p><p> Pollution expert Anthony Hedley, of Hong Kong University, warned that thousands of people could be killed by the smog which also threatened crops and stock.</p><p> "It's an absolute disaster in health terms," he said. "It's not stretching imagination too far to say if you immerse people in this tremendous pollution . . .</p><p>then I think there is nothing more predictable than a substantial number of premature deaths. There are going to be tens of thousands of illnesses and I don't think we've seen the half of it."</p><p> Professor Hedley said health effects of the haze could include chronic bronchitis, emphysema, diseases of blood vessels in the head and lung and cardiovascular disease.</p><p> Other specialists said the haze was blocking sunlight, starving plants and reducing temperatures amid a drought, a combination of factors which could devastate food supplies.</p><p> "It will destroy the ecology of the region," said Fang Ming, senior climatology program manager at Hong Kong University of Science and Technology.</p><p>"Insects, animals and vegetation alike will be largely destroyed."  The situation deteriorated in the worst hit area yesterday, the Malaysian State of Sarawak, Borneo, where the capital, Kuching, was virtually cut off from the world after shipping and air traffic were disrupted by poor visibility.</p><p> In The Philippines, the haze reduced visibility in the southern cities of Puerto Princesa, capital of the western island of Palawan, and Zamboanga.</p><p> In Tokyo, the Japanese Government said it was considering sending doctors and forest fire experts, while the US and Canadian embassies in Kuala Lumpur announced partial evacuations.</p><p>Malaysia's Star newspaper carried reports that tourists were cancelling holidays to the region while Thai officials were forced to close Trang airport in the country's south amid growing fears there that the lucrative tourist industry would suffer further harm.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4SMN-16M0-TX5N-00GV-00000-00The Family secret's out2008-05-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisETCPg. 23The Family secret's outDavid Costello

Shadowy group the Family wields power behind the scenes in the US, writes David Costello

GOD and money are the great levers of American power. Deals are made and alliances forged at prayer sessions around Washington.

Political redemption also comes through Jesus.

The disgraced Bill Clinton prayed with Billy Graham while others go to Chuck Colson, the Watergate jailbird who became America's most celebrated evangelist. These men are known around the world.

But author and academic Jeff Sharlet says they do not have the clout or connections of Doug Coe, the leader of a secretive fundamentalist group known simply as the Family.

That is a big call given that Coe is ``off the radar'' and essentially invisible as a mover and shaker. Although the organisation has been around since 1935, he is best known as the organiser of the National Prayer Breakfast, held in Washington each February.

But Sharlet's expose, which combines investigative journalism and history, is intriguing, startling and ultimately convincing.

Coe and his followers are ``avant-garde'' fundamentalists who target Washington's elites by setting up prayer cells around congressmen and generals. There are no passwords or secret handshakes but members are discreet and told not to commit deliberations or deals to paper.

The network extends to pro-American foreign leaders, some of them dictators. The late Indonesian president Suharto and Somalia's bloodthirsty strongman Siad Barre were ``brothers'' of the Family. They prayed with congressmen, oilmen and arms dealers. Later some lucrative business was done.

The scary part is that Coe admires the leadership models of Adolf Hitler, Mao Zedong and even Osama bin Laden, who built disciplined organisations around a fanatical core.

There is, Sharlet writes, something disturbing about a ministry which ignores traditional Christian teaching and which celebrates power for the powerful. Domestically, the ministry works chiefly with conservative Republicans, but senior Democrats and even Catholics are within its orbit.

Hillary Clinton is regarded as a ``fellow traveller'' of the organisation and attends Coe's weekly Senate prayer breakfasts.

Al Gore also counts Coe as a friend.

George W. Bush is not a member, but he was famously ``born-again'' at a prayer group set up by the Family.

As an investigator, Sharlet is first-rate. Much of the material here comes from interviews and a treasure-trove of confidential documents. He managed to infiltrate the Family on its ground floor by gaining admission to Ivanwald -- a house in Arlington, Virginia, where some of the next generation of cadres is schooled. As a part-Jewish New Yorker, Sharlet was an unlikely recruit among a crew of preppy, athletic young devotees who spend their time praying and playing endless scratch games of basketball.

The author is fascinated by a 1989 Coe speech in which the minister admired the fanaticism of Maoist Red Guards who were prepared to kill their parents rather than betray the cause.

It is this that sets the Family apart from mainstream conservative groups -- such as the Southern Baptist Convention -- which focus on opposing abortion, gay marriage and gun control. Coe's followers, writes Sharlet, broadly support these stances but their eyes are on the big prize, a ``world government under God''.

Should anyone be worried about congressmen, judges and mayors who meet in prayer cells?

Sharlet says it does matter and points to what the organisation has achieved since it was founded by Norwegian immigrant Abraham Vereide in Seattle in 1935.

Then it was called the Fellowship and it was an alliance of conservatives opposed to communism and labour unions. By 1944 Vereide's prayer groups involved a third of the members of Congress. During the Eisenhower presidency, he started the National Prayer Breakfast and expanded his influence into the military and the CIA. During the 1950s, Vereide worked with the Pentagon and the CIA on a worldwide anti-communism propaganda campaign and he supported US involvement in Vietnam.

Coe took over in the late 1960s and decided to go underground, as he ``crafted ever more complex hierarchies behind the scenes''.

Sharlet is not an angry liberal and the tone of the book is balanced, reasonable and often good humoured.

The author likes the young men at Ivanwald even as he wonders why the handsome young heterosexuals such as ``Jeff C'' were so overdosed on Jesus and running they had no time for women.

In some ways Sharlet admires fundamentalism and recognises its place in American history -- from the Mayflower to the ``Great Awakening'' of preacher Jonathan Edwards in 1735 and on to Bill Graham and the current flock of televangelists.

And he recognises its resilience, noting that the scandals surrounding Ted Haggard and Jimmy Swaggart strengthen the faithful in a way that a forest fire clears the underbrush.

But his exasperation rises when he contemplates how Suharto and other dictators benefited from their Family connections. In 1970, Suharto had a meeting with a Senate prayer group attended by secretary of defence Melvin Laird. Over the next two decades, Family-linked congressmen backed arms sales to Indonesia even as its military invaded East Timor and slaughtered its civilians. This, Sharlet writes, made them ``brothers in blood''.

It is unlikely that this book will cause any great concern in America's power elite.

The author, who is editor of TheRealer.org, first wrote about Ivanwald in 2003 for Harper's magazine and there have been a smattering of articles about Coe and Vereide in newspapers over the years.

But it will give outsiders a better picture of US fundamentalism in its most pure and disturbing form.

The Family: Power, Politics and Fundamentalism's Shadow Elite

by Jeff Sharlet (UQP, $34.95).

urn:contentItem:4P8B-RM70-TXN5-S0NY-00000-00All clear, but jockey pays high price in Hong Kong2000-12-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisSPORTPg. 13All clear, but jockey pays high price in Hong KongRACINGTONY BOURKE

Even for Hong Kong these days, $75,000 for a round of drinks is rather steep and as Greg Childs ruefully counts the cost of having a relaxing chat with some Australian racing writers after Sunline's win in the Hong Kong Mile, it is worthwhile having another look at the circumstances that led to what is an extraordinary decision.

On one hand, the stewards, headed by Australian John Schreck, have imposed the heaviest financial penalty ever incurred by an Australian jockey and in the next breath they have stated categorically there was no wrongdoing involved.

The report issued by Schreck at the end of yesterday's inquiry is one of the most detailed and comprehensive this writer has ever seen from any stewards' inquiry, yet the bottom line, which says "there was no evidence to suggest Childs was involved in any dishonest practice", must leave him at the very least somewhat puzzled and should be a clear warning to any other jockey or trainer venturing to Hong Kong.

The report also states that "during the course of the inquiry, the stewards made it known to all those before them that they are unaffected by public demonstrations and by pressure from the press. They know that if they are influenced by such matters, it will lead to injustices to licensed persons. This is one occasion that the stewards believe they should defend the licensed people under their charge and accordingly they wish to place on record that no evidence was uncovered which would even in the slightest way suggest that the Hong Kong Mile

was subject to any corrupt practices."

Now, in due deference to Schreck and his panel, it is patently clear that yesterday's inquiry would not have even got off the ground had it not been for "pressure from the press".

As misguided or naive as the writer of the original article that led to what became a veritable furore might have been, Schreck had no alternative but to open an official inquiry once the local press in Hong Kong got hold of it.

It is just as obvious now that by finding Childs was not guilty of any dishonest practice but slamming him with the maximum fine, that the stewards were looking for a scapegoat to stem what had become a forest fire of innuendo in Hong Kong.

After many sensational rorts in Hong Kong racing over the years before the end of British rule, some of them involving Australians, the Hong Kong Jockey Club, is particularly sensitive of its image.

The HKJC's international race day has developed into one of the great race meetings in the world.

So, the merest suggestion in the context of the offending article - what were really nothing more than a couple of throw-away paragraphs - was inevitably going to bear the brunt of officialdom.

As well as questioning Childs and Justin Sheehan, four other jockeys who rode in the race and Australian trainer David Hayes, the stewards reported they had "looked carefully" at the five 1600-metre runs of Adam this year.

They noted the consistent manner in which Adam had been ridden and said his run in the Hong Kong Mile at Sha Tin had fitted "perfectly into that pattern".

Childs told the inquiry he had been instructed, if possible, to ride Sunline somewhere just off the pace as it was anticipated the race would be run at a fast pace from the outset and that some of those horses drawn inside Sunline would go forward.

But because of the manner in which the race was run in the early stages, Childs said he elected to go forward and lead.

Childs told the stewards he did not agree that he made the comments attributed to him in the Sydney Morning Herald although he said he had an off-the-record social conversation with a Melbourne journalist and two other people who were, at the time, not known to him.

There is no doubt that in future the old wartime maxim "loose lips sink ships" will become Childs' motto.

urn:contentItem:7VHV-6JM1-2RR2-D02W-00000-00The Top Ten - What everyone was talking about this week2009-04-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisINSIGHTPg. 2The Top Ten - What everyone was talking about this weekWarwick McFadyen

What everyone was talking about this week

1 FIREBALLS of quot;atomic forcequot;, quot;indefensiblequot; areas of the state - these were two descriptions to emerge from the first day of formal hearings of the Bushfires Royal Commission. Jack Rush, QC, counsel assisting the commission, also gave an indication of how indefensible when he said the blazes probably reached an intensity of 100,000 kilowatts per square metre. The maximum that a forest fire can be controlled is about 4000 kilowatts per square metre. Even in the glory of a Melbourne autumn, the traces of smoke were still in the air from the burning off of more than 3000 hectares on the city fringes in the past week.

2 RICHARD Pratt, billionaire businessman, arts patron, philanthropist, Carlton Football Club tragic, and price-fixer, is close to death. Pratt, 74, was diagnosed with prostate cancer in 2007, but his health recently deteriorated dramatically. Prominent Australians, including Premier John Brumby, who described him as a quot;great Australianquot;, this week paid tribute to Pratt. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission has criminal charges pending against the businessman. However, his lawyer Leon Zwier said Pratt did not want the charges dropped because he was dying, but because he believed he was innocent.

3 IT'S the word that dares not speak its name, at least to the Prime Minister. This week Kevin Rudd said he believed it was inevitable Australia would enter a recession. Reserve Bank governor Glenn Stevens said we were already there. quot;I think the reasonable person, looking at all the information available now, would come to the conclusion that the Australian economy, too, is in recession,quot; Stevens said. The International Monetary Fund agreed. However, in the same week came news that the global financial crisis may be eased by Da Vinci Code author Dan Brown. His latest book, The Lost Symbol, is due out this year. It may be an economic stimulus and reading non-stimulant all at the same time.

4 WHILE attack and counter-attack were launched over Australia's border protection policy, the immediate fate of asylum seekers from the boat that exploded last week was decided by a simple matter of geography. The Age reported that those who were taken from their sinking boat to the oil rig Front Puffin cannot apply for refugee status because the rig is in territory excised from Australia. Those who were taken to Darwin can apply for refugee status and appeal if their application is rejected. Another boat of asylum seekers was intercepted during the week off Western Australia, and another was being tracked by the navy heading towards the coast.

5 MELBOURNE is booming. In fact, it is experiencing the largest urban growth ever seen in this country. In the past two years, the city's population has risen almost 150,000, putting it on track to hit 4million by year's end. The Australian Bureau of Statistics, in figures released this week, said most of the growth had occurred on the city's fringes, with Wyndham leading the way.

6 THE civil war in Sri Lanka between Tamil Tiger rebels and the Government was heading for a showdown that many observers believe could end in widespread bloodshed. The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam this week ignored an ultimatum to surrender, thereby triggering a push by government forces to defeat them. The United Nations estimates that 4500 civilians have died in fighting in the past three months.

7 TWELVE months ago, Australia's best and brightest descended on Canberra to cook up a storm of ideas as part of Kevin Rudd's 2020 summit. This week, of the 962 ideas to emerge, nine were given Government blessing. These were: a) quot;golden gurusquot; as workplace mentors; b) teams of civilians to respond to overseas emergencies; c) an Australia-Asia Endeavour Awards Scheme; d) an ABC children's channel; e) a round table of business and school connections; f) a carbon challenge initiative; g) a broadband network involving training and universities; h) an indigenous cultural centre; and i) $50 million for bionic eye research.

8 LAST week, US President Barack Obama referred to Bush administration memos detailing CIA interrogation measures as reflecting an America that had lost its quot;moral bearingsquot;. This week, he left open the door that those in the previous administration who approved such torture may be liable to prosecution. Attorney-General Eric Holder is investigating. A congressional inquiry may also be established. Mr Obama has said the CIA agents who did the torture, in effect those who were following White House orders, would not be held accountable.

9 TEN former directors and executives of James Hardie were found guilty of having broken the law by making misleading statements about the adequacy of a compensation trust fund for victims of asbestos-related illness. Justice Ian Gzell, in the NSW Supreme Court also found that James Hardie itself was guilty of misleading conduct. The guilty, including former James Hardie chairwoman Meredith Hellicar, face heavy fines and bans from serving on company boards. It is believed Hellicar and others will appeal.

10 THEIR armies were defeated, but their love was unconquered. The couple were Marc Antony and Cleopatra, who more than 2000 years ago killed themselves to avoid Roman capture. William Shakespeare turned their lives into a tragic love story wrapped in the cloaks of empire. At play's end Octavius says: quot;She shall be buried by her Antony/No grave upon the earth shall clip in it/A pair so famous.quot; This week their final resting place, which has been lost under the sands of time, may be nearer to revelation. Zahi Hawass, general secretary of Egypt's Supreme Council of Antiquities, claimed that the Taposiris Magna temple, 50 kilometres from Alexandria, could be the site.

urn:contentItem:48H9-14H0-015H-D0K6-00000-00<published>2003-05-04T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:56:44Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Grief town farewells 'angel' and her sons</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>NICK TAYLOR</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">PAUL Stallard's family spent yesterday morning in one last bid to find the young man lost in a tragic fishing accident.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> A few hours later they farewelled the mother and brother he had fought desperately to save from the unpredictable ocean.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> They were joined in their grief by almost the entire 600 population of Nannup, the South-West town left stunned by the loss of three of its own. Many more who had been touched by the tragedy travelled to the timber town for the funeral.</p><p>Deborah Stallard, 49, was washed off rocks by a "king" wave while on an Easter fishing trip to remote Black Point, 30km southeast of Augusta.</p><p> Andrew Stallard, 19, jumped in to save his mother, followed quickly by his 25-year-old brother, Paul, while their father, Ron, 57, tried to get them all to safety using rope and driftwood.</p><p> Only the bodies of Mrs Stallard and Andrew have been recovered.</p><p> Yesterday the tiny wooden Catholic Church of St Thomas More at Nannup was filled with family and friends and hundreds more gathered outside for funeral services for Mrs Stallard and Andrew and a memorial service for Paul.</p><p> The town was eerily silent with main street shops and businesses closed as a mark of respect, and a sprinkling of white ash from a big forest fire fell on the congregation.</p><p> Father Matt McPhee said the community would never forget the brothers' sacrifice for their mother.</p><p> In a eulogy for Mrs Stallard, lifelong friend Julie McDonald said: "Deb loved being with her family and friends. She had a special gift of making people feel loved. She radiated happiness and love and</p><p>realised her dream of having a large family. They were her pride and joy."</p><p> Sarne Mellema described his friend Andrew as a free spirit with a unique sense. Cousin Sarah Stallard said Andrew was the kindest person she knew. Brett Heffernan said his longtime mate, Paul, was a dedi cated family man and a good friend -- "more like a brother" -- who died a hero.</p><p> The two young men had driven home for Easter from Perth where Andrew was a marine biology student at the University of WA and his brother had taken time out from his university studies to work for a steel company.</p><p> Dozens of people have signed a condolence book.</p><p> One wrote simply: "Deb was an Angel on Earth." Another said the writer would always remember Mrs Stallard's smile and kindness, and Paul and Andrew as very special people whose lives set a wonderful example.</p><p> Shire president Barbara Dunnet, a close friend of the family, said the town was stunned as news of the tragedy spread. "People couldn't believe what had happened," she said. "We were numb. Then everyone started bonding together. They became tight-knit and wrapped around the family.</p><p> "Some people still can't talk about it and don't sleep. I wake up in the middle of the night wondering why it happened and how shocking it all is."</p><p> Mrs Dunnet said Mrs Stallard had been "an integral part of the community . . . in occasional care for young children, scouts, guides, the historical society . . . so well respected that some people would not leave their children with anyone else but her".</p><p> She added: "Some people called her the second Mother Theresa. They thought she was a saint. Bringing up seven children never fazed her. She was as steady as a rock. Her family was everything to her. It was all she ever wanted."</p><p> Mrs Stallard's brother-in-law Geoff has become the family spokesman. He described this week how the family was still in shock and had searched the coast every day, living in hope that Paul's body could be found before the funeral.</p><p> "It's a thing in you that refuses to accept we are not going to find Paul and bring him back," he said. "You go down to Black Point believing that you are going to bring him back, but the days end in tears.</p><p> "The support from people in the town, their moral support and simply being there if you want them, has been remarkable.</p><p> "The family is binding together well. There will never be a closure to this. There will only be another day, another stage, that we will all have to live through."</p><p>  *  A trust fund set up by the local council to help the family cover the funeral costs has already reached $5000. It remains open.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:7VK7-RPG0-YBDY-R132-00000-00YOUR SAY2009-05-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisPg. 12YOUR SAY

Rich gets the gobbledegook he is seeking

Speeches of Premier David Bartlett often contain comments along the lines of ``People in the street tell me . . .'' -- and what they tell him is often at odds with the official advice he has been given.

By taking unrepresentative comments out of context, properly prepared science-based evidence can be wiped away.

An example of this is in John Rich's article `Home-grown gobbledegook' (Over the Fence, April 17).

We cannot tell the size or representative nature of his sample, but we do know his question: would people be prepared to pay more for organic produce?

To ensure he gets the ``no'' answer, he paints a picture of poor-quality fruit and vegetables.

This not only elicits the answer he is after; it gives readers of Tasmanian Country the impression that organic food is not as good for you as non-organic produce.

Through many properly conducted studies worldwide, this has been found to be far from the case.

Furthermore, the idea of poor-looking organic fruit and vegetables is now out of date.

Indeed, the picture in the article shows how organically produced vegetables can look.

Rich's main message is that consumers will continue to need to buy fruit and vegetables -- and this is true.

The demand for organic food is still growing, and Tasmania is the best place to produce it.

JIM ROSSITER

convener

Organics Tasmania

Official view on burning issue

I would like to clarify several points about fire management in David Byard's article `Grasp this burning issue' (Chews the Fat, April 24).

The onset of climate change, higher temperatures and drier conditions does require new ways of thinking so that the risk of bushfire continues to be properly managed.

Recognising that bushfires are likely to become more frequent in a warmer climate, the Tasmanian Government announced in 2007 a statewide strategic fuel-reduction burning program to reduce bush fuel loads and, in turn, to reduce the risk to lives and property posed by uncontrolled bushfires.

Under this initiative, the state's three fire-fighting agencies -- Forestry Tasmania, the Parks and Wildlife Service, and the Tasmanian Fire Service -- are using their combined expertise to undertake strategic fuel-reduction burns across the state.

This autumn, the three agencies have been individually undertaking scheduled burns.

Last week, the first of the co-operative burns was completed at Lake Leake on the East Coast.

The objective of that burn was to create areas of bush with low fuel loads to help prevent large bushfires.

Further burns are scheduled as weather conditions permit.

We accept that fuel management is a fundamental responsibility of all land managers, and it assists in reducing the potential for damaging bushfires.

Indeed, the Parks and Wildlife Service is endeavouring to do more burning than it has in the past.

It must be understood, however, that fuel-reduction burning does not solve the problem of wildfires by itself, but it does make controlling and extinguishing wildfires easier.

Yes, planning fuel-reduction burns is a process that should consider environmental and social impacts, such as smoke impacts on communities.

Proper planning for burns does take time and we are working hard to streamline our planning processes.

However, as a community, and from the legal aspect, we have a lot of expectations and obligations that cannot be ignored.

Finally, it must be remembered that fuel-reduction burning is not the only factor to consider in regard to the safety of communities during bushfires.

We have seen only recently in Victoria the disastrous implications that extremely severe fire weather can have on communities.

That and other factors will no doubt be carefully considered as we try to better manage this risk.

PETER MOONEY

general manager

Tasmania Parks and Wildlife Service

Put metal in roadside fences

The January Epping Forest fire (`Sparks over fence fire claim, April 24) clearly demonstrates that roadside fencing built with treated pine strainer assemblies, posts and droppers can be totally destroyed by fire.

This allows stock to escape on to roads, thus creating a traffic hazard.

The use of metal strainer assemblies and droppers and making at least every second post metal -- while not entirely solving the problem -- would result in most fencing remaining stock-proof after fire.

It is surprising that many new roadside fences on the East Tamar Highway reconstruction project still have treated pine strainers and posts.

Property owners should insist that all replacement roadside fencing be constructed using metal strainer assemblies and droppers and with at least every second post being metal.

LINDSAY MILLAR

Hillwood

We can still let nature save us

Why is Prime Minister Kevin Rudd focusing on an industrial-dream version of ``carbon capture and storage'' (CCS) to tackle our carbon emissions problem when the most effective and efficient system already exists in nature: trees and plants?

Timber companies cutting down our forests through the industrial age have caused the climate change crisis by depleting the natural CCS system.

For this, the timber industry should be held entirely legally and financially accountable.

And it should be made to pay in full for the remedy.

To think that, somehow, another (so far unrealised) man-made industry could do any better, or even anywhere near as well, as nature is ridiculous.

The concept toys with our very existence on this planet.

It can only be considered in the way we think about that other fairytale -- ``clean coal''.

Perhaps we can all now look forward to living in gingerbread houses with Hansel and Gretel.

Mr Rudd, get real, for goodness sake.

The simple way to achieve emissions reduction through CCS is to protect what forests we have left and plant more trees elsewhere.

Go for a drive just about anywhere in country Australia and you will see cleared paddock after cleared paddock, areas that were once treed.

Just have a look at the old photos on the walls of our country pubs.

RUSSELL LANGFIELD

Kimberley
