urn:contentItem:4MJK-2TS0-TX52-K25H-00000-00Why are their lawns watered?2006-12-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisLETTERSPg. 14Why are their lawns watered?

I FEEL compelled to step up on my soapbox for a minute and say a few words about water.

We live on a small farm in the Western District.

We are in the same boat as most: we do not have a lot of fresh water and stock water is limited.

So we scrape and save every last drop and feel guilty when we don't.

Recently, we embarked on a trip to another world, a much different world to our stark, dry and dusty paddocks.

This world resembles a paradise. The grass is so green and the lawns are expansive and watered daily, allowing water to run wasted and unused into the storm water drain unnoticed.

This world is Robinvale in the north.

We are all aware of how precious our water is. Yet I don't think the people of Robinvale and Euston are aware that there is a drought happening, let alone a water crisis.

While my partner and I shower with our feet in buckets so we can water the chooks and the lemon tree, Robinvale residents continue to drain the Murray River on to their front lawns.

I have nothing against irrigators. They contribute to the economy and they feed us but a front lawn half the size of the MCG won't feed too many mouths now will it?

Name and address supplied

Donald's warm welcome

DONALD, the small town in the Wimmera Mallee that we love and live in, is experiencing the drought as much as any community in Australia.

Country people are bound to a lifestyle that is threatened and difficult but has to be lived in order to feed our cities.

While our crops fail and incomes shrink, keeping our town alive through commerce is difficult.

However, this small, resilient town has a great tourist potential, which the people here rarely advertise, except through their warm, natural manner.

They display friendliness, honesty and a time-rich approach to life.

But now they need help from the city, but not a handout.

All we ask is for city people, with their steady incomes, to visit the country to do their Christmas shopping.

Come up for a long weekend to spend a dollar or two in the bush to keep our shops open and our businesses here.

Donald businesses, through the Donald Chamber of Commerce, have banded together in a promotion to put up a $10,000 prize, which shoppers can win. It's a generous effort to keep businesses alive.

So, please, city cousins, come up to Donald, spend the weekend in quiet relaxation, in a friendly, spacious shopping precinct.

Help Donald fight the elements, and enjoy your stay in comfortable, friendly surroundings.

We look forward to your company.

Tony Phillips, Donald

Burning truth about neglect

AS THE drought continues, forests in our water catchments are parched.

Fires are burning uncontrolled on both sides of the Great Dividing Range, some perilously close to the source of Melbourne's dwindling water supply.

The Murray-Darling Basin Commission has confirmed from previous research that a major high-intensity fire decreases the water harvested from eucalyptus water catchments by almost half.

Water flows do not return to normal for about 100 years.

Flows into the Murray and Snowy rivers are now starting to show the effect of the huge 2003 bushfires.

Those fires were the result of inadequate fire suppression and environmental neglect that prevented sensible fuel management.

Both those vital services were historically provided by foresters, the timber industry, hydro-electricity workers, graziers and, before them, the indigenous people.

Now, under a ''lock-up'' policy, there are very few people taking care of the catchments in our beautiful high country.

Victoria's forest fire management system failed, not only in the 2003 bushfires, but also last year when a 20ha prescribed fire was botched in Wilsons Promontory National Park.

It failed again in January this year when fires devastated national parks and private property in the Grampians and Brisbane Ranges.

The Bracks Government has consistently manipulated due processes to avoid proper scrutiny of its policies and actions and acknowledge the obvious -- that the system is not working.

The Stretton Group was formed to bring the burning truth (literally) of fire, fuel and management of public land to public attention through greater transparency of the public sector processes involved.

It is too late now to do any more than hope and pray that an uncontrollable Ash Wednesday-type feral fire will not affect Melbourne's water catchments in the next two months.

If a disaster happens the community will demand a royal commission.

Could Melbourne people tolerate their catchments' water harvest being reduced by 50 per cent because of one huge bushfire?

Stewart McArthur, Bill

Middleton, Athol Hodgson,

Dr Peter Attiwill, Simon

Paton, David Packham,

The Stretton Group

Where is the GM information?

LABELLING on products at my local shops does not give me information on which canola oils are genetically modified, or which vegetable oils contain GM cottonseed oil, or whether the corn syrup found in a variety of goods is from GM corn, or which animal products are derived from GM grain-fed animals.

How are consumers supposed to make judgements when such information is not available?

Janet Grogan,

Joondanna, WA

urn:contentItem:4MK1-2KF0-TX4S-M2VV-00000-00Grassroots policing2006-12-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisAPg. 18Grassroots policingThe Canberra Times

SOME serious scenes around Cooleman Ridge at Chapman earlier this week when police swarmed on the neighbourhood and cordoned off an area to investigate someone acting suspiciously on the reserve, possibly with a gun. A spokesman for ACT Policing said yesterday the report was received on Tuesday morning but luckily the suspicious character with a gun turned out to be only a person spraying weeds on the reserve with a spray gun. "We get lots of things where people are ringing up and saying there is suspicious activity and we respond and we find out that it's, after all, something quite legitimate.

It's just a standard thing that we do," the spokesman said. The area was locked down for less than 15 minutes, he said. "When [police] arrived they stopped access for about 14 minutes until we found the guys who were spraying the weeds and that was the end of it," he said.

Fighting-fit firies THERE is no doubt the 50 ACT Rural Fire Service members who have been sent to battle the forest fire near Tumut are among the fittest in the territory. The Rural Fire Service has three levels of fitness for its volunteers and departmental firefighters: light, moderate and arduous. All the firefighters who were sent to Tumut have reached arduous level meaning they passed a test of completing a 4.8km walk in under 45 minutes while carrying a 20kg pack.

Tough stuff. The volunteers also have accommodating bosses, allowing them to go to the fire on leave without pay, or, in some cases, with pay.

Christmas jeer SOME staff believe they are getting mixed Christmas messages at the head office of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs in Belconnen. On the one hand, staff were praised for raising more than $2000 to buy Christmas presents for 60 Canberra teenagers in an office whip-around. "The Christmas spirit is truly alive here in the national office!" an e-mail to them read. But at least one worker thinks the department is being stingy for not reimbursing staff for the Christmas decorations they put on their work stations and around the office. All staff were informed in an email from the financial strategy and reporting division that "Christmas decorations cannot be purchased with corporate funds". "Please note that the costs of decorations CANNOT be reimbursed.

Any decorations must be purchased with your own money.

Reimbursement forms sent to Financial Services Section will be returned to the relevant officer." The accusation it was being a little bah- humbug brought a swift response from the department, with a spokesman saying "taxpayers' money must be used appropriately when it comes to departmental expenses and activities". "While the department has put up some communal Christmas decorations in the lobby, it would be remiss to use taxpayers' money to decorate individual staff areas within the department," he said. "Of course, people are free to hang decorations within their work areas. However, it is reasonable and appropriate for these to be bought privately." The spokesman also pointed out that DIMA staff had raised $40,000 throughout the year for charities with raffles, trivia nights and various whip-arounds.

Emptying the bath CANNY kangaroos have shrugged off the drought and found a steady source of fresh water in the garden of Judi Power Thomson at Hall. "Last week I erected a bird bath for the hot and thirsty birds," she said. "It took three days before our resident kangaroo family discovered this little gem. They now empty the bird bath every day." Judi took this photograph from her kitchen window, with "dad, mum and the kid" kangaroo now visiting each afternoon.

Pollie with no voice ACT Opposition Deputy Leader Jacqui Burke is in the extremely frustrating position of being a politician without a voice, literally rather than figuratively. A virus nine weeks ago has attacked her vocal chords, temporarily paralysing part of them, meaning she can only speak in a whisper. "It's been the most distressing nine weeks of my life," she said. "It's like a landscape gardener who has to go to work with their hands tied behind their back. My voice is the tool of my trade." Burke hopes a break over Christmas will restore her voice and get her fit and ready for next year. "I love my job and I've got so much to give," she said. "It couldn't come at a worse time with me accepting the position of Deputy Leader." She does see some sort of silver lining to the cloud, saying it has given her some extra empathy for people with a disability in the workplace.

Rudd in demand PASS the turkey, Kev. Labor's new leadership duo of Kevin Rudd and Julia Gillard are the political couple most wanted at Christmas dinner tables this year, beating the John Howard and Peter Costello partnership with four times the votes, according to a survey conducted by Australian marketer to women, The Heat Group. The online survey, which questioned 277 Australian women of all ages, showed foxymorons Kath and Kim, winners of last year's poll, were again the most-wanted duo (living or dead) to have at the Christmas table with 31 per cent of votes. Bono and Sting were the next most popular (17 per cent).

urn:contentItem:566B-NJS1-F0JP-W50X-00000-00Massacre triggers debate on punishment and mercy2012-07-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 20Massacre triggers debate on punishment and mercy

top priority

Readers discuss the relationship between popular culture and violent behaviour.

Inhumanity not right

IS it one-eyed to consider an eye for an eye? Then the alternative is not only the loss of sight, but every other sense as well.

Rebekah Devlin (The Advertiser, yesterday) quotes those who selectively draw on the Bible/Torah, yet does not mention that this saying is about proportion, and mercy.

There appears to me nothing merciful about prison, especially American-style incarceration and nothing quite as barbarically inhuman as wishing someone a ``long and miserable existence . . . (as) . . . better revenge''. Isolation is an incredibly effective punishment, principally when followed by reconciliation and an embrace.

By all means decry the death penalty, without becoming callous or inhuman in the process.

BRENTON CARBINS, Adelaide.

Death paid for sin

BIBLICAL instructions certainly include loving and forgiving our enemies, along with repaying ``an eye for an eye'' - as noted by columnist Rebekah Devlin (The Advertiser, yesterday).

Old Testament retributive provisions helpfully restrain outrage by limiting the response to match the crime.

But forgiveness under the new covenant is based upon renewal by faith in Christ.

His death paid the price of sin, and enables God to pardon sinners - who are therefore empowered to love.

DAVID d'LIMA, Sturt.

God will be the judge

REBEKAH Devlin's ``An eye for an eye is not the solution'' (The Advertiser, yesterday) is thought-provoking.

No matter what is done to James Holmes following the shootings in the cinema, nothing can compensate the relatives of the victims. God will be the ultimate judge, whether he dies of natural causes in the end or is given the death penalty.

Many who face the penalty of death apparently fear God and repent of their crimes. As God promises forgiveness for all sin, and we all do sin (albeit not on such a scale), God sees all wrong as sin and needs our repentance or words of sorrow for them. God wants us to do good, not evil.

B.V. HAMILTON, Bordertown.

Weapons are worse

ALI Carle is correct in that previous generations in Western society have been more violent in their day-to-day life than we are today (The Advertiser, 23/7/12).

That does not mean we have gone far enough in tackling violence. Much more can be done. With the weapons available today, one act of violence by an individual is shown to be far more damaging than in any previous period. An individual with a knife, a sword or a bow and arrow would not cause the slaughter we now see.

I believe the level of violence we now witness in movies, mainly produced in the US, is little different to the Viking burial or hollow brass cow to which Ali refers.

I do acknowledge there is a need for some members of our society, such as our farmers, to possess a weapon. Beyond that, no person in a civilised society needs to own firearms unless they intend to kill or maim. Societies that are obsessed with the ownership of weapons, such as the US, are far from being civilised.

ERIC TAYLOR, West Beach.

Guns all around us

GUNS are all around us. First there are the official ones: experts with guns, hundreds of thousands involved in wars, defence force reserves, state troopers, police, security companies, the armaments industry, etc.

Then there are the ``non-official'' ones: gun and hunting clubs, hobbyists, farmers.

With high winds it is very difficult to stop a forest fire. In society, madness prevails.

RAJ DAYAL, Blackwood.

Director `baffling'

I WAS amazed to see the comment from the director of the Batman trilogy regarding the cinema massacre.

``Movies are one of the great American art forms. That someone would violate that innocent and hopeful place in such an unbearably savage way is devastating.''

It seems obvious to me that this sad event is a logical result of decades of sickening violence coming out of Hollywood and I wish filmmakers would lift their game and make some non-violent movies for a change. How he could refer to his movies as innocent and hopeful is quite beyond me.

But I am a voice in the wilderness, completely out of step in a society that considers violence as entertainment and kicks up a fuss if the censors try to regulate what appalling images we are exposed to.

HEATHER LAUTERBACH, Victor Harbor.

Sorry, Mr Nolan

WHILE absorbing the media reports of the newly infamous ``Batman killer'', James Holmes, my jaded responses were rattled by a comment attributed to Christopher Nolan, the director of the Batman Trilogy.

Sorry, Mr Nolan, but my personal belief is that you and other movie directors should hang your heads in collective shame at some of the unbelievably violent, sick, perverted and mindless muck that you have been producing for years.

To suggest that the cinema is a place of innocence and hope is hopelessly naive, inappropriate and out of kilter with reality.

BILL CUNNINGHAM, Goolwa.

Media mayhem

THERE is a lot of talk about gun bans in the media, but little about the glorification of gun violence in films like The Dark Knight Rises and Gangster Squad, with a trailer for the latter preceding screenings of the former in some cities that contained a scene involving the mass shooting of a movie theatre audience.

Batman trilogy director Christopher Nolan (``Dark night'', The Advertiser, 22/7/12) said: ``Movies are one of the

great American art forms. That someone would violate that innocent and hopeful place in such an unbearably savage way

is devastating.''

If the media corporations that produce such movies believe the gratuitous depiction of gun violence, including massacres, is a legitimate form of entertainment, it follows that depicting lunatics driving cars into crowds at high speed is also innocent and a legitimate form of entertainment.

Yet few if any movies do so. Because it would be irresponsible? Do the elites who control the mainstream media (consciously or unconsciously) want to promote shooting sprees in order to disarm the mob, or are they simply indifferent to the consequences of their actions? They seem fixated on banning guns for some reason. No talk about media violence or mental health from them, just ``guns bad, ban guns''.

RICHARD LUTZ, Seacliff.

Industry to blame?

JAMES Holmes is a mass murderer. There is no doubt about that.

So does that make the movie industry ``accessories before the fact''?

ALISON J. REYNOLDS, Trinity Gdns.

Bolt `in disguise'

ANDREW Bolt praises Batman's efforts against the revolutionary Left (The Advertiser, yesterday). Where was Batman during the worst global right-wing wars of the 20th century? Could it be that Bolt is a Joker in disguise?

DON BILNEY, Blackwood.

Society in question

OF course the crazily lax gun laws of the US and its mad gun culture were not to blame for America's latest senseless massacre - just ask the all-powerful

gun lobby.

And this is the nation that claims it has the best system of society in the world and thus has claimed the right to invade many countries in the past 50 years.

In the process, millions of innocent people were killed in a bid to force those invaded to copy Americans' supposedly superior type of society.

ANDREW SCHOLEFIELD, Rostrevor.

As ye sow . . .

AT least unlike so many massacres of total innocents before, this one happened at a commercial event promoting the infecting of children's minds with dark, psychotic, violent, vigilante-ish ideas. And it happened to people who by being there and paying their admission supported that. As ye sow, so shall ye reap.

GORDON DRENNAN, Burton.

Here's to Heroes

HEROES Walk Away is a great initiative as it represents a step towards reducing mindless acts of violence in our community (The Advertiser, yesterday). Engaging a thug serves only to embolden his ways. To walk away in recognition of the danger is a measure of real manhood.

BRIAN COOMBES, Para Hills.

urn:contentItem:4P0N-JXD0-TXN5-S37X-00000-00A burning issue for the US west2003-01-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisNEWSFeaturesPg. 13A burning issue for the US westPerspectiveJohn Schauble

The deaths of 20 firefighters and the destruction of almost three million hectares of wildland in the United States in the past year has put fire management high on the agenda. In 2002, there were 71,160 wildland fires in the US, burning through more than 2.8 million hectares, according to the National Interagency Fire Centre in Boise, Idaho. This is about double the 10-year average. The superlatives flowed through the northern summer - there were some of the biggest, most damaging and protracted fires in the country's recent history. Hundreds of homes were lost, whole towns threatened. Some of the worst-affected states were in the west, which has a long history of

fire and fire suppression. It shares with south-eastern Australia and parts of

the Mediterranean rim the distinction of being one of the most fire-prone areas of the world. The recent experience of the US has been one of increasingly severe wildfires affecting broader expanses of wildland forest. In 1988, Americans watched in horror as fire cut a swath through Yellowstone National Park. In 2000, they welcomed assistance from overseas, including Australia, as wildfires bit hard in the western states. That year more than 122,000 fires burnt through 3.4 million hectares. The fires prompted debate in the US over whether land managers need to burn the

forest to save it. By comparison, in Australia - especially Western Australia - land managers have always used fuel-reduction burning as a way of combating the threat of bushfire. Over the past century, the US has developed a range of techniques to fight wildfires. These have included using water-bombing aircraft, hot-shot paratroops and platoons of dedicated paid ground firefighters, together with a huge army of volunteers across the nation. But the realisation has been slow in coming that however much hardware and technology you throw at it, wildfire is a natural phenomenon that long predates

man's intervention. Over much of the past century, US land managers have been fixed on the idea that fire must be excluded at all costs from the forest. The no-fire philosophy

can be traced to devastating, uncontrollable fires that obliterated entire towns and decimated timber reserves in the early 1900s. That experience spawned

a US Forest Service and a campaign that saw fire as the enemy of the landscape

and exclusion as its aim. Enter Smokey Bear, a cartoon poster character so successful in proselytising the no-fires message that his fame spread well beyond the US. Then came Disney's Bambi fleeing the destructive forest fire deliberately set by the villains who killed his mother. Such messages were drilled into the American psyche and their impact is still felt today. As fires have become bigger and more threatening to forests and wilderness areas and to the people living on their fringes, debate has shifted to whether total fire-exclusion policies adopted across the US are appropriate. In one of the more intelligent recent assessments of the "burn versus don't burn" debate, retired US forester Stephen Arno and science writer Steven Allison-Bunnell have examined the issue as it relates to the western forests of

the US. Differing forest regimes aside, there are plenty of parallels with the

Australian experience. Whether fire helps or harms the environment, they argue, is largely a matter of

perception. Humans have been conditioned to see fire as purely destructive, rather than helpful. They say part of the problem is that the US public is so confused about the place of fire in the natural environment that it is not sure

what to believe. What appears clear from Arno's and Allison-Bunnell's analysis is that after prevention and mitigation, fire suppression is tantamount to failure in environmental management. "It does not treat the underlying cause of the problem," they conclude. Reintroducing fire into the western US forest regime is an acknowledgement of its original role in maintaining a healthy ecosystem. After a century of fire exclusion in the US, just how this can be done while satisfying the competing social, political and land-use interests is another matter. Precisely the same challenge will face Australian land managers who have moved away from using prescribed burning as a key management tool. Flames in Our Forest: Disaster or Renewal by Stephen Arno and Steven Allison-Bunnell, Island Press, $US19.95, www.islandpress.org

urn:contentItem:4P8B-RHP0-TXN5-S1DY-00000-00BRIEFS2000-06-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisNEWSIn Brief OverseasPg. 13BRIEFSWORLD

Nuclear secrets on missing hard drives

WASHINGTON. Two computer hard drives containing vital nuclear secrets have disappeared from a vault at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico, laboratory and US Energy Department officials disclosed. Department officials first learned that the nuclear secrets were missing on June 1 and have not ruled out the possibility that the disappearance is linked to a forest fire that threatened the lab and forced its evacuation last month. The two hard drives contained material used by the Nuclear Emergency Search Team, which is trained to respond to nuclear accidents of terrorism threats. They contain data needed to render weapons safe in an emergency or as part of a threat by terrorists.

Former pupils sue Hare Krishna group

DALLAS. More than 40 former students of Hare Krishna schools have filed a $400 million lawsuit against the religious movement, alleging they were sexually and physically abused as children over two decades. The suit filed in federal court named the International Society of Krishna Consciousness, the movement's umbrella group, as the lead defendant along with 16 local organisations, 17 governing board members and the estate of the movement's founder, Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada. The lawsuit alleged children in Hare Krishna boarding schools were routinely abused by teachers and staff from 1972, when the society's first school opened in Dallas, until about 1990. The abuses ranged from rape and beatings to forcing small children to stand for hours in a darkened closet or sleep in soiled blankets as punishment for wetting their beds.

Coup leader brought to book

RIO DE JANEIRO. The former Paraguayan general accused of inspiring last month's failed coup was brought to Brasilia on Monday to await extradition to his homeland. Lino Cesar Oviedo, a controversial populist politician, was arrested on Sunday in southern Brazil. He was officially being sought in connection with his role in an attempted coup in 1996. But the search for the former military leader, missing since early last year, took on new urgency last month after factions of the Paraguayan military and police tried to overthrow the government of President Luis Gonzalez Macchi.

Putin appoints Chechnya leader

MOSCOW. Russia's President Vladimir Putin has appointed a Muslim cleric to govern Chechnya, a move intended to legitimise the Russian intervention in the breakaway republic. Mr Putin said the new leader, Mufti Akhmed Kadyrov, a Chechen, would have the support of his people. But many Chechens distrust leaders who have sided with the Russians, and it will be difficult for him to establish authority. Aslan Maskhadov, the president of Chechnya before the Russians intervened in 1994, has denounced the mufti as a traitor. The cleric has already been the target of several assassination attempts, including a bombing last month that wounded his son.

Dancer wins implants suit

NEW YORK. A former exotic dancer won $30,000 in a jury verdict yesterday after she sued her plastic surgeon for using breast implants to enhance her buttocks. Mary Gale, 43, of North Miami, Florida, accused Dr Elliot James of negligence and malpractice in the November 1990 procedure. Ms Gale said that she suffered mental anguish and physical pain, and was no longer able to earn $US500 ($A845) a night dancing in men's clubs. She now works as a bartender. "I'm glad we won the case. Breast implants belong in the breast area," Ms Gale said.

Mexican police die in ambush

TUXTLA GUTIERREZ. Seven police officers were killed on Monday when unidentified armed men ambushed a patrol in Mexico's troubled southern state of Chiapas, where Zapatista Indian rebels took up arms six years ago, an official said. The attack occurred about 110 kilometres north-west of the state capital, Tuxtla Gutierrez. Two other people were injured. Chiapas has simmered since the Zapatista National Liberation Army rose in rebellion in 1994, demanding improved rights for Mexico's 10 million Indians.

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Vic: Bushfire threat to Bright eases for now</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Jewel Topsfield and Susan Murdoch</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>BRIGHT, Vic, Jan 22</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The north-east Victorian town of Bright is on high alert tonight, with residents nervously watching the progress of a fire closing in on a nearby pine plantation.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Fears that the fire would take hold in the plantation at Devils Creek, 6km from Bright, and jump to the town eased by 8pm (AEDT) with a drop in the wind.</p><p nitf:lede="true">But fire authorities and residents of the town of 2,000 people were remaining vigilant.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"As a result of some feverish activity, the immediate threat to Bright has been averted on the basis of pretty good weather conditions," Department of Sustainability and Environment (DSE) spokesman Alan Everett said.</p><p>"It's still possible it will go up the ridge and go up there quickly, but at the moment with backburning, we're hoping it won't go that far."</p><p>The residents of several nearby towns are also on full alert as, for the second night in a row, 16-day-old bushfires encroach on townships in the picturesque region.</p><p>Last night, four homes and a shed in the hamlets of Stanley, Yackandandah and the Indigo Valley were destroyed by fires which authorities believe may have been deliberately lit.</p><p>Fire authorities this evening advised the residents of Bright, Porepunka and Wandiligong to either leave for safe shelters immediately or stay and defend their properties.</p><p>DSE spokesman Stuart Ord said the crews were preparing for unpredictable behaviour from the Buffalo fire encroaching on Bright.</p><p>"The fire is becoming extremely erratic and hard to predict," he said.</p><p>"With hot conditions expected this weekend, the fire intensity may well increase."</p><p>Mr Ord said humidity in the region was down to just four per cent, with more severe conditions expected on Saturday.</p><p>Residents at Harrietville were urged to activate their fire plans and remain on high alert with spot fires from the Bogong bushfire slowly heading towards the Alpine hamlet.</p><p>Eight fires in the north-east and Alpine country are continuing to burn, while another fire this afternoon broke out in a pine plantation near Linton, west of Melbourne.</p><p>Linton was the scene of the 1998 tragedy in which five firefighters died when their truck was engulfed in flames.</p><p>The Country Fire Authority (CFA) said the fire burned up to 50ha, at one stage endangering houses on the Linton-Snake Valley Road before being contained by 8pm (AEDT) without damaging property.</p><p>Another fire on the outskirts of Melbourne at Lysterfield, which was thought to have been deliberately lit, was brought under control at about 3pm (AEDT).</p><p>CFA chief fire officer Russell Rees said this morning that three fires which threatened Yackandandah, Stanley and the Indigo Valley began in quick succession.</p><p>"The origin of these fires are suspicious … and are being investigated by police," Mr Rees told reporters.</p><p>More than 8,900ha had been burned at Eldorado, and up to 4,000ha was razed in Stanley, with the flames racing through grassland, scrub, plantation pines and box ironbark country.</p><p>However, Mr Rees said given there were 130 houses directly in the path of the fires, the efforts of firefighters and the community had worked well.</p><p>"It's outstanding that the losses were so small," he said.</p><p>By mid-afternoon, the Eldorado and Stanley fires had slowed along the frontlines and firefighters were controlling its flanks.</p><p>Relief centres were established at Wodonga, Chiltern, Beechworth, Myrtleford and Bright for residents who fled their homes.</p><p>CFA spokesman John Worthy said about 8pm the Eldorado fire had been contained at the top of a ridge near the Indigo Creek Road.</p><p>"It remains a fairly significant threat to some property in the towns of Indigo Valley, Worragee, Barnawartha South, Barunduda and Wodonga," he said.</p><p>Mr Rees said firefighters were working frantically ahead of forecast extreme conditions over the weekend, but he said with conditions so dry after five years of drought, the fires were continuing to burn regardless of temperature or wind direction.</p><p>"There has been 15 days of solid fires. In my view there is no end in sight," Mr Rees said.</p><p>Meanwhile, exhausted firefighting crews were today relieved with reinforcements from around the state.</p><p>A team of forest fire experts from New Zealand had also been sent to the Gippsland fires near Omeo, which were burning through dense, rugged country.</p><p>Meanwhile, the state's bushfire crisis has affected horse racing, with Racing Victoria transferring tomorrow's eight-race meeting scheduled for Wodonga to Seymour, north of Melbourne.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2003</dc:source><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-02-28</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="748"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2003 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4FFX-JX40-0045-53WS-00000-00<published>2005-02-12T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:56:44Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>A;</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Come fly with pigs in space of pure delight</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>The Canberra Times</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">HICH two things do Beatrix Potter, Plutarch, Charles Lamb and George Orwell have in common? In their different ways, they all wrote about pigs, and they figure among the 301 items in Lyall Watson's biblio-graphy. A notable omission from it is Jeffrey Masson's The Pig Who Sang to the Moon (reviewed here on March 28), though perhaps The Whole Hog was already in press when Masson's book came out. Watson is a naturalist, with interests in fields as diversely related as biology, anthropology, palaeontology and archeology. People have written popularising scientific books about geese, whales, cats, dolphins, chimpanzees and many other animals, which are sometimes seen as mere humans in disguise, a lesson to us all as embodiments of simple nobility, fair-mindedness, tolerance and fun. Masson's book was explicit advocacy of the right of the pig (and the duck, and the goat, and the cow, etc) to be treated by us as decently as we treat our fellow humans. Watson doesn't go that far, though he does present many arguments in favour of seeing pigs, both wild and domesticated, as close to human beings not only through history and culture, but in their eyes and teeth, as well as in other evolutionary consequences of being omnivorous, characteristics such as curiosity, play and interest in novelty. He sees them as having a better claim than dogs to be called "man's best friend" (besides, he says, they taste better). As Churchill said, "Pigs look you in the eye as equals."</p><p>About 30 years ago, a French novelist, Jean Giono, wrote a light-heartedly learned article about pigs, in which he said that the adage about nothing in a pig going to waste, except the squeal it makes at the moment of slaughter, has been rendered obsolete by technological progress, for now even the squeal is used, by being recorded, then minced into sound effects by radio producers and filmmakers. Watson seems not to have heard of this, but it seems a small omission from a book that combines great erudition with engaging humour. It may seem an odd thing to say of a book about pigs, but it is exhilarating, offering constant intellectual fodder, served with a refreshing humanism of manner and felicitous use of language. The author contrives to make his reader believe that this fascinating porcine lore is essential knowledge and that to learn so much about pigs from a single book is to be more human. In part, this is because he writes not just about pigs, but about the roles they have played and continue to play in human life and cultures. The only problem it poses is how anyone could write such a brilliant book about pigs. After reading it, Desmond Morris said that if anyone ever called him a swine, he would take it as a compliment. The title says it all, both in style and contents: the book covers most aspects of all pigs, ancient and modern, free or captive; and the author's way of writing about his subject is a constant delight, vivid, sprightly, evocative, hugely informed and neatly inventive in turn of phrase. Take this, from a description of a herd of white-lipped peccaries in the Amazon jungle: "noisy, barking and squabbling, moaning and retching like football fans on their way home from a lost match. You can hear this hullabaloo from a hundred yards away, but the sound of a herd in a palm grove carries much further. Each crack of a hard nut shell sounds like a pistol shot, and the effect of a hundred fruits being opened and devoured in quick succession has to be heard to be believed. It combines the menace of an approaching forest fire with all the staccato explosions of a Chinese New Year celebration." Think of any English expression about the family Suidae (the learned name for pigs of whatever species) and you will find as many sentences in this book where the author plays on it with an amusing twist to its tail: pig in the middle, when pigs can fly, on the pig's back, hogging the limelight, pig ignorant and so on. The very fact that there are so many locutions and so much mythology, from the old "This little piggy went to market" to the newer Miss Piggy, is no doubt testimony to the ambivalent closeness of our relationship to pork. The book is solid suidology from beginning to end, but the science is leavened with anecdote, personal experience and a lightness of manner that make the book readable to anyone who appreciates a dash of style in the service of knowledge. It is a model of how a literate scientist can make science, its premises, its methods and its implications for us all accessible to the non-scientist. James Grieve, as a reader, is as omnivorous as a pig.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:459J-DXN0-0197-T07J-00000-00<published>1996-04-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:56:44Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>IN BRIEF</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Fire closes on nuclear plant A FIERCE, four-day forest fire whipped by unpredictable winds blackened more than 4400 hectares in New Mexico as it crept toward a nuclear weapons laboratory. "The state's ready to go up in flames," said Governor Gary Johnson, who took a helicopter tour of the area yesterday. "This is the driest it's ever been." Sixteen backpackers in the area had all been accounted for yesterday. About 800 firefighters were battling the blaze, which began on Thursday.</p><p>Orwell got that one right A GOVERNMENT tax bureau in China has given an Orwellian twist to its anti-corruption campaign, urging the spouses of tax officials to inform on their partners. The China Daily said officials in the Jilin province bureau were responsible for assessing local business taxes _ a practice that provided dangerous opportunities for bribery. George Orwell's novel 1984 envisaged family members spying on each other.</p><p>Thousands pay last respects THOUSANDS of people from all walks of life have queued patiently to pay their last respects to Indonesian first lady Tien Suharto at her parental home in Solo before she is laid to rest on a nearby hill. The coffin, bedecked with the Indonesian flag and strings of flowers, was placed in a traditional open-air reception pavilion at Tien Suharto's birthplace. The wife of Indonesian President Suharto died on Sunday of a heart attack at the age of 72.</p><p>Iran cracks down on smoking IRAN'S parliament has approved a law banning smoking in public places, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported yesterday. The law will ban smoking in mosques, government offices, factories, banks, hospitals, theatres, buses, restaurants, schools and universities. Violators will face fines.</p><p>Ravine bus plunge claims 31 A PACKED bus plunged off a road and fell into a ravine in Peru's southern Andes on Sunday, killing at least 31 people and injuring at least 20, some critically. The bus plunged 300m off the road near Estiquepampa, an area of narrow roads and precipices.</p><p>Police said a mechanical failure was likely to have caused the accident.</p><p>The bus was overcrowded.</p><p>Apartment fire kills 12 AN apartment fire killed a dozen people and injured four others in the Mexican city of Tijuana, officials said yesterday. "The 12 dead . . . the bodies were completely burned," a firefighter said. A spokesman for the coroner's office in the border city said one of the dead was a boy about 12 or 13 years old. Details of the other fatalities were not immediately available. The fire began in what Alvarez described as one of Tijuana's oldest apartment buildings.</p><p>Spanish architect wins top award SPANISH architect Jose Rafael Moneo has been named the 1996 winner of his profession's highest honour, the Pritzker Architecture Prize.</p><p>Moneo, 58, who lives in Madrid, becomes the first Spaniard to receive the prestigious honour. During a June 12 ceremony at the construction site of the Getty Centre in Los Angeles, Moneo will be presented with the $A127,210 prize and a bronze medallion.</p><p>Nuclear waste ship forced back A NUCLEAR waste ship that protesters prevented from docking at an island housing Taiwan's only atomic dump returned on Sunday to Taiwan.</p><p>A spokeswoman for state electricity utility Taiwan Power Co refused to comment further.</p><p>Bombs go off in Athens TWO bombs exploded in a popular central Athens square yesterday, slightly injuring two policemen and causing panic among hundreds of people seated at nearby outdoor cafes, police said. It was unclear whether urban guerrillas or criminals placed the bombs in a shopping complex on a pedestrian walkway leading into Kolonaki Square, a popular evening rendezvous.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4P8B-H2Y0-TXN5-R15J-00000-00BLOODLINES2000-03-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisSPORTThe FormPg. 17BLOODLINESJOHN HOLLOWAY

Orton moves

* PETER Orton, one of Australia's most respected horsemen, has been appointed national manager of Vinery Australia.

In a decision which surprised many, Orton will be leaving Arrowfield Stud after 17 years as general manager to take up the Vinery position.

Orton has been part of Arrowfield's great rise in the breeding industry.

Arrowfield chairman John Messara praised his contribution and wished him well. He said Arrowfield would not be replacing Orton.

Vinery's owner, Dr Tom Simon, required a top hands-on horseman to take over the management of his Australian breeding set-up, which includes the Roselands Stud in Victoria, and Orton's background fitted the bill perfectly.

Flying start

* MESSARA surprised a few breeders with the release of his 2000 stallion service fees for Arrowfield last Monday.

He has based his prices on supply and demand and has received 200 inquiries about Flying Spur this year.

Flying Spur has made an excellent start to his stallion career and up to last weekend had produced eight individual winners of 13 races from just 24 representatives. He is third on the prizemoney list.

The fee increases of the Arrowfield team are Flying Spur from $17,500 to $35,000, Danzero from $12,500 to $25,000, Snippets from $20,000 to $25,000 and End Sweep from $25,000 to $30,000. Redoute's Choice, the $10 million horse, begins his stud career at a fee of $30,000. All prices will be subject to GST.

The fees for Timber Country ($30,000), Unbridled's Song ($25,000), Fuji Kiseki ($20,000) and Brocco ($15,000) remain unchanged, while the other newcomer to the Arrowfield line-up, Xaar, commences at $22,500.

Full house

* BREEDERS looking to gain a service to last year's Golden Slipper winner Catbird for the coming season can save themselves a phone call to Yarraman Park Stud.

I've been advised that house full sign has been posted just a fortnight after the announcement of the three-year-old's retirement to stud and his arrival at Yarraman Park. Catbird, which is standing at a fee of $12,500, is another great example of the demand for young stallions by Danehill.

Zabeel strikes

* NEVER underestimate a champion . . . what a difference a week makes . . . it's never over until the fat lady sings.

Put them all together and you can see why champion stallion Zabeel isn't giving in without a fight as he tries to retain his Australian sires title over Danehill for the 1999-2000 season.

The quinella in last Saturday's $1 million Moonee Valley Oaks put Zabeel within striking distance of Danehill.

Within a week Zabeel's progeny won $831,050, compared with Danehill's offsprings' winnings of $185,285. He now trails Danehill by only $305,200.

Forest fire

* WIDDEN Stud's Charnwood Forest - rated by many as one of the best-looking stallions in the world - has shown he isn't only a pretty face by notching first win as a freshman stallion from his first runner.

The win by two-year-old Blue Forest gave comeback jockey Walter Swinburn his first success in two years after his battle with weight problems. Blue Forest, which cost 38,000 guineas, won at Newcastle, England, on Tuesday.

Charnwood Forest is close to being pitch-black and has left his stamp on his progeny, just as his sire, Warning, did.

Charnwood Forest, which stands at $12,000, will have eight yearlings at the Easter Sales.

Impressed

* AUSTRALIA'S biggest owner-breeder, Jack Ingham, returned from his invitation from Sheikh Mohammed for last weekend's Dubai Cup meeting with glowing reports about the facilities and Dubai Millennium.

"The Sheikh's set-up is amazing," he said. "His stables, which are known as the Zabeel stables, feature six blocks which are air-conditioned, close to the working tracks and boasting the best equine swimming pool I have ever seen."

He said Dubai Millennium, the winner of the Dubai World Cup, hit the ground running and repelled all challengers to win easily in record time.

urn:contentItem:4K00-S5T0-TXDB-C2HP-00000-00Herculean effort brings WA fire under control2005-01-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisPM5:38 PM AESTABCDavid WeberHerculean effort brings WA fire under control

TANYA NOLAN: Firefighters and emergency workers have been battling a massive, deliberately lit, bushfire in Perth's eastern hills for five days now.

It's one of the biggest fires Western Australia has seen for many years and the State Government is offering a $100,000 reward for any information that leads to the arsonist being identified.

David Weber filed this report.

DAVID WEBER: I'm deep in the State forests at the forward control point near Mundaring Weir. There's about 20 firefighters taking a well earned break here eating and drinking and generally kicking back.

It's an eerie atmosphere. We're surrounded by smoke from the smouldering forest. And there's the strange sight of city taxi cabs occasionally coming down the dirt track to take exhausted firefighters back to hotels and motels.

FIREFIGHTER: Oh we've been here since Saturday night, seven o'clock Saturday night we first got called out.

DAVID WEBER: So you must be pretty tired?

FIREFIGHTER: Yeah, we're buggered, yeah. I've got ... oh we rotate our guys out on a sort of 14, 16 hour basis. But it sort of catches up with you with the smoke and the fire and all that, and just the conditions, yeah.

DAVID WEBER: How long have you been here for?

FIREFIGHTER: Since Sunday.

DAVID WEBER: And how do you think this operation's come off?

FIREFIGHTER: Oh ... it looked pretty disappointing there for a while, but I hope it's under control. I mean, no one's got caught as far as I know, which, happy with that. I mean, and the houses haven't gotten burnt down, so that's a good result, I think.

FIREFIGHTER: It's been hard because we're running out of crews, and our group is a specialist group, and we can't just take anybody. We've got to use specialists, and people are getting tireder and tireder. We're glad that we're probably going to run another shift tonight and hopefully we'll pull our transportable gear down.

DAVID WEBER: The statistics are staggering. More than 20,000 hectares burnt and a perimeter of around 150 kilometres. The fire was so fast that in some places it charred the lower part of the forest and left the tops of the trees untouched.

The Department of Conservation and Land Management, or CALM, has responsibility for the fire because it's in the State Forest.

Fire-controller Kevin Haylock.

KEVIN HAYLOCK: I'd have to say it's been an absolutely Herculean effort by FISA, by the Government agencies, and by the private individuals involved. And I can only liken it to a group of school kids going out and performing in an AFL Grand Final. It's been an elevation of effort that's surpassed everyone's expectation and been a very, very good effort and a good result.

DAVID WEBER: I've been told that there was a lot of fuel in the area and when they're trying to push the fire back to somewhere to bring it under control there was a lot of fuel there as well. Has this park been perhaps not as managed as well as it could have been?

KEVIN HAYLOCK: Look, one of the things that we have tried to do in Western Australia in fire management for the last decade is to be very responsive in regard to putting smoke over the city. And certainly there has been less prescribed burning in this area than we would want to have achieved, and there are fuel loadings greater than 10 years, and it's very difficult for us to be able to catch a fire, to contain it, and actually full suppress it when the fuel is much greater than 10 years old. And so that has certainly been an issue.

DAVID WEBER: The isolated communities around this area were under alert for a long period of time. How have they managed the situation?

KEVIN HAYLOCK: There has been some evacuation from properties. So there's been dislocation of peoples' livelihood. There has been fire in pasture and orchards, so there will be some damage there to peoples' incomes.

There has been a great deal of uncertainty from the community because there is a huge pall of smoke that is coming out of this fire, and once the fire is out, or contained, the smoke doesn't actually stop. There are numerous logs on the ground spread over 15,000 hectares that will smoulder for days and days, and so whenever the wind shifts it shifts that pall of smoke in that direction of course, so there's been a great deal of concern from people who all of sudden see smoke coming their way that they think there may be another fire outbreak, and it's been a task to try and reassure the community that we are actually making good progress.

TANYA NOLAN: Kevin Haylock, a fire-controller in Perth's eastern hillside, speaking to David Weber.

urn:contentItem:4P7M-CWR0-TXN5-R298-00000-00BORROWING FROM OUR CHILDREN1990-06-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisSPECIAL SUPPLEMENTPg. 60BORROWING FROM OUR CHILDRENWORLD ENVIRONMENT DAYSTEPHEN SKINNER Environment Reporter

"WE do not inherit the earth from our ancestors - we borrow it from our children."

That saying is especially appropriate to the theme of this year's World Environment Day: "Children and the Environment".

The responsibilities it places on the present adult generation are awesome

Degradation of the environment is killing children even now.

But children themselves could help adults come to grips with the problems, according to the Executive Director of the United Nations Environment Program, Dr Mostafa Tolba.

"Young people are often among the first to understand the implications of the destruction of natural resources - and to try to prevent it," said Dr Tolba.

"Indeed, some have already achieved substantial success."

Dr Tolba, an Egyptian, said the success stories included:

* More than 1,000 Indonesian scouts planted 100 hectares of trees in East Kalimantan after a forest fire destroyed the water catchment area for 25,000 villagers.

* The Young Conservation Volunteers - formed by a group of unemployed Zambian teenagers - kept a major National Park clean. They also performed anti-poaching plays for villagers, which dramatised how conflict for space between farmers and wildlife can be resolved.

* The National Youth Environmental Protection Council of Hungary held its second festival of environmental films made by young people recently - and polluting industries who were cleaning up their act helped sponsor it.

* At the ripe old age of 13, Andrew Holleman of Massachusetts in the USA led a successful campaign against a harmful development of a wetland site near his home.

* Children - especially young adolescents - were the driving force behind the "green consumerism" movement in developed countries, by telling their parents what to buy.

It is such happenings which have made Dr Tolba hopeful for the future.

Over the last year there had been a significant increase in the space, time and prominence devoted to environmental issues in the media, he said.

And a recent international poll of both rich and poor countries revealed mounting public concern for the global environment.

"The world is beginning to recognise that our quest for ever higher material living standards is on a collision course with the environment," said Dr Tolba.

"In the past, we commonly assumed that the next generation would live on a planet with an environment very similar to ours - and perhaps with new technology to make life safer.

"This assumption is no longer justifiable.

"We have to constantly ask ourselves: 'Will this action help meet our present needs, while not jeopardising the needs of future generations?'.

"The situation is serious now and likely to become worse as the present global population of more than five billion increases.

KILLING THE POOR

"It may double by the middle of the next century, and about 90 per cent of the growth is expected to occur in the developing countries."

Dr Tolba said the degradation of the environment was killing mostly the children of the poorest parents in the poorest countries.

He said their growing bodies and minds were less tolerant of disease, pollution and malnutrition than those of adults.

UNICEF figures showed that diarrhoea and other illnesses related to unsafe water were killing millions of children each year.

And air pollution played a major part in the annual four million deaths from breathing system infections of children from developing countries.

In the industrialised nations, the major environmental killers were air pollution and hazardous chemicals.

Two Illus: MOSTAFA TOLBA TREE PLANTING: Children's awareness of the destruction of natural resources gives hope for the future.

urn:contentItem:49M5-J4R0-01S8-D3FP-00000-00<published>1990-04-09T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:56:44Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>GOLD TV GUIDE; Pg. 14</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>TODAY'S MOVIES</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>PRITCHARD D</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">SUNDAY, APRIL 15 D A Y T I M E</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Mister Roberts (Ten, noon): The 1955 adaptation of the Broadway hit play about a World War 2 rusty navy supply ship in the Pacific is an ingratiating comedy. Begun by John Ford and finished by Mervyn LeRoy, Henry Fonda, William Powell and Jack Lemmon's battles with tyrannical captain James Cagney see them all at their comic peak.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Reluctant heroes. 8 Hard Knox (Nine, 2 pm): The 1984 telemovie pilot, directed by Peter Werner, for Robert Conrad's Baa Baa Black Sheep series, as yet unseen here. Marine career flyer Conrad is grounded and must choose between a desk job and running a military school full of misfits. Guess what he takes on.</p><p>As in school of . . . 5 E V E N I N G The Ten Commandments (Ten, 7.30 pm): Cecil B. De Mille's formula for biblical epics (nine reels of sin to one of repentance) never worked more profitably than in this 1956 spectacular. Charlton Heston's stolid Moses endures life in Pharaoh Yul Brynner's court. After betrayal and the seven plagues he leads the Israelites across the parted Red Sea into the wilderness. The Top Ten look as if they are inscribed by a thunderbolt-activated laser writer. Unsubtle primary-level script and acting.</p><p> The Exodus project. 6 Lawrence of Arabia (Seven, 8.30 pm): See Movie of the Week, page 7.</p><p> The Last Wave (Nine, 8.30 pm): Lawyer Richard Chamberlain defends Aboriginal David Gulpilil and learns that his nightmares are part of a Dreamtime legend that Sydney will be engulfed by a tidal wave.Peter Weir's 1977 film is strong on atmosphere.</p><p> Damper dumper. 7 F O R N I G H T O W L S</p><p> Coach of the Year (Nine, 10.40 pm): Wheelchair-bound Viet-vet Robert Conrad agrees to teach his football skills to a group of delinquents.This afternoon's Hard Knox had more series potential; this busted 1980 pilot, directed by Don Medford and Andy Sidaris, is a better film and built around a similar theme.</p><p> The behind-bars team. 6 Fire! (Nine, 12.50 am): Producer Irwin Allen claimed his disaster-movie formula was to start with a catastrophe, then build to a climax. It works fairly well in this 1977 telemovie, directed by Earl Bellamy, with a forest fire racing towards a mountain community. Like a whodunnit, the trick is to guess who in the semi-star studded cast will survive.</p><p> Schematic, but passable. 6 School For Secrets (Ten, 1.50 am): Conceived as a documentary follow-up to The Way Ahead, Peter Ustinov's 1946 film instead became a feature about the boffins who developed radar.Starring Ralph Richardson, it's interesting but afflicted by elements of its 25-year-old writer-director's precosity.</p><p> Back room boys. 5 In This Our Life (Nine, 2.45 am): Bitchy Bette Davis ruins sister Olivia de Havilland's life by stealing her husband Dennis Morgan.But she gets her just desserts in a car crash. John Huston's disappointing directing follow-up to The Maltese Falcon, many of whose cast plus father Walter can be seen as extras in a bar scene. Davis never stays still; she was obviously expecting potshots for this neurotic melodrama.</p><p> Unsisterly. 5</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:42DR-95V0-0048-T1S5-00000-00<published>2001-02-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:56:44Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Features</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>People and Places</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>People and Places<br/><br/>STORIES OF PEOPLE AND PLACES AROUND THE WORLD<br/></p><p nitf:lede="true">US Shipwreck<br/></p><p nitf:lede="true">HANOVER, Maryland, Feb 22 AP - A deep-sea salvage company claims<br/>to have discovered the deepest ancient shipwreck ever found - a<br/>2,300-year-old Greek trading vessel found nearly over three km<br/>under the surface of the Mediterranean.<br/></p><p nitf:lede="true">The discovery by crews from Hanover-based Nauticos could change<br/>theories about ancient trade routes and provide clues about climate<br/>change in the past two millenniums. Details about the find will be<br/>reported on Monday in the magazine Archaeology, the company said.<br/></p><p nitf:lede="true">The wreck was found almost 500 km off the coast of Corsica while<br/>the company was working for the Israeli government, searching for a<br/>submarine that disappeared in 1968.<br/></p><p nitf:lede="true">Company general manager Tom Dettweiler said his crew members at<br/>first were unhappy that the thing they discovered wasn't the sub.<br/></p><p>"They called me back sounding really disappointed and said,<br/>'It's this really old ship'," Dettweiler said. "I got pretty<br/>excited."<br/></p><p>The discovery was made in May 1999, but was kept secret until<br/>the salvage of the Israeli submarine - which the company eventually<br/>found - was completed.<br/></p><p>Oceanographer Brett Phaneuf of the Institute of Nautical<br/>Archaeology at Texas A&M University estimated the wreck's age using<br/>video images of amphorae, large ceramic containers used to<br/>transport olive oil, wine and other commodities. Their appearance<br/>suggested they came from the Greek islands of Rhodes and Kos and<br/>were made around the second and third centuries B.C., the company<br/>said.<br/></p><p>The discovery of the wreck between the trading centres of Rhodes<br/>and Alexandria, nearly 500 km from land, could challenge the<br/>thinking that ancient Mediterranean trading ships generally didn't<br/>venture into the open sea.<br/></p><p>"We'd always believed that ships hugged the coast and stayed in<br/>sight of the land," Phaneuf said. "This is the nail in the coffin<br/>on that theory. These ships are as far as you can possibly get from<br/>any shore. They didn't get there by accident."<br/></p><p>AP<br/><br/><br/><br/><br/></p><p>Sci Extinction<br/></p><p>LONDON, Feb 22 PA - A giant comet or asteroid smashed into the<br/>Earth 250 million years ago and triggered the biggest mass<br/>extinction in history, scientists said today.<br/></p><p>The disaster was even more catastrophic than the impact which is<br/>thought to have ended the reign of the dinosaurs 65 million years<br/>ago.<br/></p><p>It resulted in almost all life - 90 per cent of all marine<br/>species and 70 per cent of land vertebrates - being wiped out.<br/></p><p>Scientists call the event at the boundary of the Permian and<br/>Triassic periods The Great Dying.<br/></p><p>But only now has evidence come to light linking the destruction<br/>with an object hitting the Earth.<br/></p><p>Researchers who reported their findings in the journal, Science,<br/>today said the impact probably did not wipe out life directly.<br/></p><p>Rather, it triggered a series of events, including the most<br/>furious period of volcanic activity the world has ever seen, that<br/>made survival impossible for the great majority of species.<br/></p><p>It happened 250 million years ago, occurred again 185 million<br/>years later, and experts warn that another major impact could<br/>destroy the human race.<br/></p><p>The US scientists estimate that the object responsible for The<br/>Great Dying was between 6 km and 11.9 km wide.<br/></p><p>They do not know where it landed on the single continent called<br/>Pangea, which comprised all the Earth's land at the time.<br/></p><p>However, the "bolide" - the term used for either an icy comet or<br/>rocky asteroid - left a calling card in the form of tell-tale<br/>chemical traces found in rare ancient rocks from sites in Japan,<br/>China and Hungary.<br/></p><p>One of the researchers, Dr Robert Poreda, associate professor of<br/>earth and environmental sciences at the University of Rochester,<br/>New York, said: "The impact of a bolide of this size releases an<br/>amount of energy that is basically about one million times the<br/>largest earthquake recorded during the last century. It was like a<br/>magnitude 12 earthquake on the Richter scale."<br/></p><p>PA<br/><br/><br/><br/><br/></p><p>US Gran<br/></p><p>MILWAUKEE, Feb 22 KRT - When a robber snatched Sylvia Bembenek's<br/>purse while she was sitting in her garage, the 84-year-old woman<br/>didn't take the matter sitting down.<br/></p><p>Instead, Bembenek threw her car into gear and gave chase, police<br/>said.<br/></p><p>Although she didn't catch the man, police said, Bembenek did get<br/>close enough to get the licence plate number of the car the suspect<br/>jumped into before he sped off.<br/></p><p>Moments later, on Tuesday, Bembenek reported the incident and<br/>the licence plate number to the police.<br/></p><p>Police said the car was soon traced to a woman on Milwaukee's<br/>north side, and through investigation, they determined that the<br/>woman's boyfriend was probably driving the car about the time of<br/>the robbery.<br/></p><p>Later that day, the suspect entered the 7th District police<br/>station and asked why police were inquiring about his girlfriend's<br/>car, police said.<br/></p><p>The 33-year-old man was immediately taken into custody on<br/>several unrelated arrest warrants. He now could face a charge of<br/>robbery in the purse-snatching incident, police said.<br/></p><p>KRT<br/><br/><br/><br/><br/></p><p>France Tractor<br/></p><p>PARIS, Feb 22 DPA - Christian Hurault, a French lorry driver,<br/>was set to leave Paris today on the first ever round-the-world trip<br/>by tractor.<br/></p><p>Hurault, who stems from the city of Orleans, south of Paris,<br/>counts on making the journey in 11 months, at an average speed of<br/>25 kph.<br/></p><p>He expects to spend some 14,000 hours at the wheel of his<br/>tractor, which was donated by the Finnish manufacturer that is<br/>sponsoring the adventure.<br/></p><p>The 43-year-old Hurault already has several long-distance trips<br/>by farm vehicle under his belt.<br/></p><p>In 1985, he drove an old, used tractor from Orleans to Bamako,<br/>the capital of the African country of Mali, carrying humanitarian<br/>aid for Mali's farmers.<br/></p><p>"It wasn't easy at the time," he recalls. "I was the first to<br/>cross Algeria by tractor. The customs officers kept me in (the<br/>capital) Algiers for a week."<br/></p><p>Four years later, Hurault crossed the Sahara on a<br/>harvester-reaper.<br/></p><p>Hurault plans to travel via Belgium, Britain, Germany,<br/>Scandinavia, Russia, Japan, Canada, the French Antilles, Morocco<br/>and Spain, completing the trip on a budget of 100,000 euro<br/>($A175,350).<br/></p><p>The Russian crossing should provide the greatest difficulty, he<br/>said, since he still had not received authorisation to cross some<br/>regions of the country.<br/></p><p>DPA<br/><br/><br/><br/><br/></p><p>Singapore Dogs<br/></p><p>SINGAPORE, Feb 22 AP - Singapore is making sure imported dogs<br/>can be identified by more than just their good looks, breed, age<br/>and sex.<br/></p><p>All foreign canines must be implanted with microchips or face<br/>deportation, the government's Agri-food and Veterinary Authority<br/>said in a statement today.<br/></p><p>The authority also wants the veterinary authorities in the dogs'<br/>home nations to certify the identity of the creatures before they<br/>can enter the city-state, the statement said.<br/></p><p>"Currently imported dogs can only be identified by physical<br/>traits such as age, breed, sex and colour," the authority said in a<br/>statement.<br/></p><p>The chip will contain health information about the dog and will<br/>identify where it came from, the authority said. A scanner in<br/>Singapore will match the dog to its travel documents.<br/></p><p>About 5,500 dogs enter Singapore each year, mostly puppies from<br/>Australia for commercial sale.<br/></p><p>The new measure, which will be enforced from May 1, also applies<br/>to pets which come into Singapore with their owners.<br/></p><p>The authority says the move will help minimise the threat of dog<br/>diseases, such as rabies, on the island. Singapore has been rabies<br/>free since 1953.<br/></p><p>Australia and New Zealand also impose compulsory microchipping<br/>of imported animals, the authority said.<br/></p><p>Veterinarians make a tiny incision, often behind the dog's ear,<br/>and insert the chip.<br/></p><p>AP<br/><br/><br/><br/><br/></p><p>US Cub<br/></p><p>CHOTEAU, Montana, Feb 22 AP - A tiny black bear cub burned in a<br/>Montana forest fire last summer was returned to the wild yesterday,<br/>its limp, sleeping body tucked by wildlife biologists into a<br/>manmade den where it will continue its winter hibernation.<br/></p><p>The one-year-old male cub, which has been recuperating in a<br/>state animal shelter since firefighters found it last August, was<br/>placed with another cub in the den on a snowy mountainside in<br/>northwestern Montana.<br/></p><p>"He's been given a second chance. The rest is up to him," said<br/>Kurt Cunningham, supervisor of the state wildlife shelter in<br/>Helena.<br/></p><p>The cub was found after a forest fire raged through the<br/>Bitterroot Valley in southwestern Montana. The animal, its paws<br/>burned and fur singed, was alone, emaciated and clinging to a<br/>charred tree.<br/></p><p>The cub was brought to the shelter in Helena, where its burns<br/>were treated and its body fattened up on a high-protein diet.<br/>Officials also tried to limit the bear's contact with humans, which<br/>became difficult as news of the orphan spread and it was styled as<br/>a modern-day Smokey Bear.<br/></p><p>"We were getting hundreds, sometimes thousands of visitors to<br/>the shelter, everyone wanting to see the bear," Aasheim said.<br/></p><p>He said biologists are confident the bear will do well once it<br/>comes out of hibernation, even without its mother. Its special diet<br/>gave it more fat reserves than most wild bears going into<br/>hibernation, and that extends the time it can survive after<br/>awakening until it finds food.<br/></p><p>"In a perfect world, you would rather they had a mother,"<br/>Aasheim said. "But if they don't, we've prepared them as best we<br/>can."<br/></p><p>AP<br/><br/><br/><br/><br/></p><p>QUOTE UNQUOTE<br/></p><p>A diplomat is somebody who can tell you to go to hell and leave<br/>you looking forward to the trip - Alex Salmond, former leader of<br/>the Scottish National Party.<br/><br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2001</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:42DR-95V0-0048-T1S5-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-27</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="1659"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2001 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4TB8-JMC0-TX5N-017T-00000-00Childs life grows anew2008-08-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisIEPg. 7Childs life grows anewSALLY BROWNE

Toni Childs had the world at her feet two decades ago when ill health forced her to give it all up. SALLY BROWNE reports on a remarkable journey of self-discovery and recovery

SHE looks exactly the same, but Toni Childs has been on quite a journey to get to where she is today.

In the early 1990s, the American singer had the world at her feet. Her debut album, 1988's Union, was an international hit, producing such memorable songs as Stop Your Fussin', Don't Walk Away and Zimbabwe.

I've Got to Go Now, from her second album, House of Hope, was a No.5 hit in Australia.

While working on a fourth album, Childs plunged herself into charity work, starting the Dream a Dolphin charity for sick children. It was then she discovered she, too, was sick. She had a disease she had never heard of. It was Graves' disease, a thyroid condition brought on by stress.

``My right eye was popping out of my head and I was waking up with my hands and feet cramping,'' she says.

``These are classic symptoms. I didn't know what it was. I thought, `I know I need to go to an eye doctor', but I was so busy and my life was so crazy. I remember I was visiting my grandmother and my Aunt Linda said: `You know what? I bet you have Graves' disease'.''

A doctor told her that her resting pulse rate was 120 beats a minute and immediately put her on heart inhibitors.

``It was a shock because each one of the doctors said I had to dismantle my life,'' she says.

She put the brakes on her projects and recording career and spent the next eight years focusing on getting well. She describes the experience as like a forest fire.

``It wipes everything out for a while, and then you have to kind of regrow, heal, rebuild,'' she says. ``You've been dismantled and dismembered. And then all your bits start coming back together and it's wonderful.

``It gives you this amazing appreciation for life and the privilege of getting to do what you love.''

What she loves is music, so Childs is thrilled to have a new album out. It's titled, aptly, Keep the Faith.

Her journey to recovery brought with it other rewards. Part of her healing ritual was to treat her body with salt rubs, reminding herself that each part of her body was beautiful.

Gradually, she was able to wean herself off her medication. The process inspired her to create a line of organic bodycare products with names such as I Love My Body and I Love My Hair. They will be released in Australia next month.

She continues her ritual salt rubs by her outdoor shower at her home on the island of Kauai, Hawaii.

It was a serendipitous meeting that led her back to the recording studio.

She was performing in a production of The Vagina Monologues, with Eve Ensler, the show's creator, in the audience. She sought out Childs after the show.

Ensler told her that her record, Union, had had a profound impact on her life. When Ensler was down in the dumps and living out of her car, she listened to the record over and over.

S HE took Childs aside and told her she needed to start singing again.

``She said, `You need to be singing. This is your gift. Why aren't you singing?' She really gave me a hard time and then she asked me the craziest thing: `OK, I want you to write an anthem that will inspire people to end violence against women and children for all time'.

``And what's really scary was I actually contemplated whether I could do it or not. That's the funny part.''

With that inspiration, Childs wrote Because You're Beautiful for Ensler's documentary, Until the Violence Stops. The song won an Emmy.

``I wanted to address how women need to know they are beautiful,'' she says. ``I think we as women are really hard on ourselves. I think we have what I call a beauty wound, needing a lot of outside reflection that we're OK . . . we give our power away.

``It's centuries old, this wound, and I think there are certain things that happened in our history which created a situation for women to stay more in the background. I believe right now that a lot of women in the world, not all women in the world, are coming into their own.''

At 50, Childs is finding her voice again, both as a speaker and a singer.

She says her new record is more rootsy and homespun than her earlier work and she believes her voice is more ``open''.

The music industry has changed a lot since her previous record -- for the better, she thinks.

``It's actually becoming more karmically balanced,'' she says with a laugh. ``It also asks the artist to become more business savvy. With computers and the internet, and also the ability to really connect with people, it's much better now.''

Her life, too, is much more balanced.

She lives on a beautiful property with two dogs, a cat, a horse named Sunny, 50 ducks and 100 chickens.

A particularly plucky rooster likes to crow outside her window to let her know it's breakfast time. Then her day begins.

In the morning she'll work online with people on the US mainland and in the afternoon, when the time is right, she'll work with people in Australia.

``I feel like there's this amazing world,'' she says.

``We've got this life and then we've got this chance to live it to its fullness and each one of us is an amazing shooting star here for a short period of time. What are we going to do with it?''

Keep the Faith is out now. Toni Childs will perform at the Corner Hotel on October 1.
