urn:contentItem:7W9K-DXG0-YBDY-R273-00000-00We can do without the dairy trade2009-08-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:44ZLexisNexisLETTERSPg. 15We can do without the dairy trade

REGARDING Melissa Eddy's opinion piece, ``Don't sit there and take it'' (WT, July 29):

We no longer ride on the sheep or the cow for income, and at present education is Victoria's biggest export earner. Australia has moved on and the assumption that the $2.8 billion dairy industries will completely stop is largely false.

What I would suggest will stop is the family farm, but let's assume Ms Eddy is correct and corporations don't take up dairy.

That is still no big deal, because we live in a global market and would happily trade ore for milk.

The argument that 40,000 additional people will be unemployed is also false.

Jobs in other areas are being created all the time. The Rudd Government is currently promising thousands of jobs from the national broadband network rollout alone.

Many farmers will take the profits from selling up and retire or start new ventures. These activities, in themselves, will create additional employment.

I'm not sure what exactly Ms Eddy finds ``interesting'' about nations who suffer war or who starved looking after their farmers.

These countries are poor, and although Ms Eddy may like to pretend we are poor, most Australians are very rich and lead rich lifestyles. She may prophesise that we will be poor, but the fact is that today we are not.

My grandparents grew all their own food and cooked it themselves. My parents grew no food, buying all their food from a shop but still cooking it themselves.

My family buys some food from a shop, cooks rarely, and often pays for the food to be delivered on a plate, at a table. My kids wouldn't even know how to turn an oven on.

Is this bad? No.

Our lives and lifestyles continue to become easier, and if that means the dairy industry is not viable in Australia, so be it.

Stop your whingeing.

Stephen Rentsch,

Hill End

Government

must act on fires

THE Victorian Government, Department of Sustainability and Environment and CFA bureaucracy are counting down the days to the next fire season, presumably to jog the public to take action to protect themselves from the onslaught of fire this coming season.

It is the Victorian Government that needs to take action.

The State Government hasn't taken notice of the recommendations of its own inquiries into the 2006 and 2003 bushfires.

The main recommendation was the funding of more fuel reduction in state-controlled forested areas. This has not happened, despite DSE having ground crew with the expertise to carry out more burns using extra resources.

There may be a slight chance of doing some burns before this season, but spring burns generally produce poor fuel reduction. Cool autumn burns are best.

Most of the dialogue from the Government and its emergency management agencies is to throw the responsibility back on the public for their own safety.

There is plenty that could be done by government agencies and municipalities before this fire season to reduce the likelihood of fatalities in the event of fire.

Public road and reserve managers have been persuaded by misguided ideals from the green lobby to let roadsides and reserves become life-threatening hazards.

Roadsides that have had natural clear areas that were a safe haven for motorists or fauna in a fire are now planted with scrub and trees by suburban-orientated ``feel-good'' groups.

Planting trees is great, but they need to be planted in the right places with the right species.

Roadsides now are linear fuses, with the ability to burn with intense unnatural heat, and authorities expect the public to use them.

Many fires start on roadsides and reserves and many vehicle accidents are connected with roadside vegetation.

Because roads have many different species of native vegetation on them, the green lobby believes roads should be left alone, without ecological burns. This belief is wrong.

The cool autumn burns of the past are why these special species are still there.

Common sense needs to prevail over misguided ideology.

Maurie Killeen,

CFA volunteer,

Valencia

Why no state

of disaster?

PETER Ryan is right to say questions directed to the CFA at the bushfires royal commission should have been asked of Emergency Services Minister Bob Cameron (WT, July 29).

Premier John Brumby also should explain why counsel assisting Jack Rush QC found ``no serious consideration was given by any witness to advising that a state of disaster, under section 23 of the Emergency Management Act 1986, be declared on 7 February.''

Born out of Ash Wednesday, the Act allowed Mr Brumby to declare a state of disaster before Black Saturday, ensuring the State Disaster Co-ordination Centre at police headquarters was fully operational and the DSE chief fire officer and CFA chief officer were at their respective operations.

That didn't happen, despite the Premier's warning on Friday, February 6, that ``the forecast conditions would make it (February 7) the worst day ever in the history of our state''.

Fires were burning uncontrolled when the Premier made his Friday statement. It was a defining moment, requiring informed leadership.

Victorians need to know why the Premier failed to exercise his statutory authority before people died on Black Saturday.

Athol Hodgson,

president,

Forest Fire Vic Inc,

Parkdale

Tribute to a

gentleman

I WOULD like to pay tribute to Ted Kenna, VC, one of Australia's most extraordinary, inspirational and gracious men, who contributed significantly towards the betterment of this country.

Ted passed away on Wednesday, July 8, shortly after his 90th birthday. I had the privilege of knowing him for over 20 years.

He was a humble man and one of Hamilton's most loved and recognised figures.

Yet, at local events, Ted was just another one of the boys. He always avoided highlighting the events that led to him being awarded the Victoria Cross for his efforts during World War II.

His humility and courage are just two of the qualities that made him a much-loved member of the Hamilton community.

On May 15, 1945, during an attack on a Japanese position, and amid enemy fire, Ted stood and confronted the enemy.

He took out an entire Japanese machine-gun crew, single-handed. Ted survived the attack, only to be shot in the face three weeks later. He spent over 12 months in hospital.

Ted loved his sport. He played football for Hamilton Imperials when he returned from the war, kicking the winning point in the 1947 WDFL grand final. He successfully coached the St Mary's under-13s for many years.

Ted Kenna was a fair dinkum, loved Australian gentleman. My condolences go to his wife, Marjorie, and his family. He will be sadly missed.

David Koch,

Member for Western Victoria
